STATEMENT BY THE SPEAKER

subdebateinfo.title: Parliament House, House of Representatives Practice (Seventh Edition)

p.span: Parliament House
House of Representatives Practice (Seventh Edition)

The SPEAKER (10:01): I have a couple of statements to update the House on two matters. The first relates to access between committee rooms and the chamber. As part of the Parliament House upgrade works, construction activity at the security guard station located at level 1 Members Hall on the House of Representatives side has commenced and will continue for a couple of months. These works will impede access between committee rooms 1R1, 1R2, 1R3, 1R4 and 1R5 and the Members Hall. If members are in a level 1 committee room and need to attend the chamber for a division, you should first move to the ground floor via either the elevators or the staircase prior to heading to the chamber. Thank you for your ongoing cooperation with these works.

The second statement I have relates to the publication of the seventh edition of the House of Representatives Practice. I'd like to inform the House about this. The seventh edition of the flagship publication Practice has been published by the Department of the House of Representatives, and, as members know well, we rely heavily on it for authoritative advice to inform our roles as chairs and as members. The content of the House of Representatives Practice is particularly important, and, quite apart from its value every day as a reliable and practical resource for our thinking and decision-making in the chamber, it has an added value. Since the first edition in 1981 it has been documenting and putting into perspective the changing and sometimes turbulent times in the life of the House in an accurate and understated way. It provides a very significant foundation to our understanding of the House as an institution. This new edition brings us up to date, with additional precedents from the sixth edition in 2012, a new chapter on the Federation Chamber, an additional chapter on the work of the committees, and discussions on the roles of members, the House, the government and the opposition. All members will be invited to a formal launch of the new edition next week. I thank the Clerk and Peter Fowler in the Chamber Research Office particularly for their contributions to what is the House's most significant publication. I also thank the large number of other staff of the House who've had a significant input to the new edition. The Clerk has provided copies to the offices of all members. I have no doubt I'll soon see lots of post-it notes and annotations on members' new copies as it's invoked during question time, and I commend the seventh edition to all members.
PETITIONS
Petitions Committee
Report
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:03): Today I present the 26th report of the Petitions Committee for the 45th Parliament.
PETITIONS
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:04): I present the following 17 petitions:
Asylum Seekers
This petition of the Refugee Advocacy Network, draws to the attention of the House:
Australia's refugee policies are cruel and destroying lives, with a number of avoidable deaths in detention.
People seeking asylum have the right to live with dignity and in safety in our community while their claims for protection are processed.
We want our society to be compassionate and just for all people, including people seeking asylum and those granted refugee status.
We therefore ask the House to:
Cease mandatory detention.
Close the camps on Nauru and Manus Island.
Process all claims for asylum in Australia in a fair and timely manner.
Refuse to deport people to dangerous or life threatening situations.
Replace temporary protection visas with permanent protection visas.
from 6386 citizens (Petition No. PN0090)
Energy

Currently, 86% of energy in Australia comes from the burning of fossil fuels, whilst only 0.1% comes from solar power. Considering Australia has the highest level of solar radiation per square metre than anywhere else in the world, it is absurd that we arenât adopting solar power more heavily into our society. Itâs free- it comes from the sun, unlike coal which we must spend millions of dollars on mining. Although solar power is expensive directly, it is cheaper than fossil fuels in the long-term. Within a few years, people wonât be losing anywhere near as much money as they wouldâve with coal. The burning of fossil fuels is the number one contributor to climate change, and if we continue to burn at the rate weâre going, by 2100, 74% of the Earthâs population will face lethal heat exposure for more than three weeks every year. Sea levels are predicted to rise by more than a metre, and storms, wildfires and droughts will be much more severe and longer-lasting. Solar power, however, can prevent this. That's why we need to embrace solar power and use it instead of fossil fuels.

To increase Australia's intake of solar energy, it should be compulsory that all new buildings to be constructed must install solar power. This would be a great start to Australia's solar intake and I ask the House to act upon a suggestion such as this that will escalate Australia's solar energy usage and lead the Earth towards a better future.
from 34 citizens (Petition No. EN0614)
Australian Constitution

Since the 2016 election several MPs have been expelled from parliament for being in breach of S44 of the constitution. Many voters have filled in reports of Commonwealth crimes and asked the Australian Federal Police to examine Commonwealth crimes committed by these former MPs in signing a false declaration to nominate for election. The Australian Federal Police advised those who lodged the crime reports that reports of Commonwealth Crimes will be ignored in relation to false declaration on nomination forms. The AFP have advised it is up to the Australian Electoral Commission to prosecute those crimes. The AEC have advised their legislation does not allow them to prosecute. The Attorney General department advised in November 2018 that they cannot tell the AFP what should be prosecuted. The Department of Home Affairs has advised it does not have control of the AFP.

The petitioners request the House determine who has responsibility for prosecuting people who breach S44 of the constitution by lodging a false declaration to nominate for election and to have the person or department or authority responsible to examine reports of Commonwealth crimes ignored by the Australian Federal Police and put the matters to a court for a decision.
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN0615)
Economy
In the budget of 2018 the government explained a lot of revenue was being lost to illegal black market tobacco sales colloquially called chop chop.

The petitioners request the House consider changing Australia's cash economy to an electronic transfer economy. This would require all sales and all transfers of funds to be electronically recorded and much easier for the Australian Taxation Office to track and prosecute those who attempt to avoid taxation and break our laws. A cashless economy for the poorest of the poor should be extended to all to stop crimes such as chop chop sales mentioned in pre budget discussions.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN0616)
Chronic Inflammatory Response Syndrome

Many Australians are suffering from a debilitating condition called Chronic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (CIRS). This condition is often misdiagnosed as Fibromyalgia, Parkinson, Multiple Sclerosis to name a few. CIRS is a form of Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS). With no formal recognition of the condition this has placed many Australians in a situation of not being treated with human dignity by the Medical Profession. Many are happy to treat but not formally diagnosis the condition. At the moment, many Australians have to fly interstate and pay upwards of $900 for a consult. With a long wait list with very few Doctors who are aware of the condition. A more formal recognition and awareness of the condition would bring a dignified diagnosis and treatment plan for all Australians who are suffering. This would result in more Australians being treated and becoming productive members of the community again. The formal recognition of the condition would also include the request to make changes to the Human Rights Act to include discrimination for those suffering from mold exposure. This illness in many cases are resulting from inadequate Work, Health and Safety Practices. I myself was affected in a Government building. If I had become aware of the environmental exposure I would not have suffered a disability resulting by exposure and facing long recovery. This situation was avoidable if full disclosure was made by the workplace.
We therefore ask the House to: I request the House establish an inquiry into Chronic Inflammatory Response Syndrome and related conditions.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN0617)
Cybersecurity

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House's to the importance of citizen's data privacy and security on the Internet. We believe is important that Australia now review and improve the digital rights of its citizens. Regulation of commercial data collection and increased accessibility to data privacy options has the power to improve civilian, commercial and national security, as well as significantly reducing both the economical and psychological impacts of regular and inevitable data breaches, data leaks and internal data abuse. These issues affect all of society, including young children and teenagers. Many nations, including the EU and UK, realise the far-reaching implications of citizen's data privacy and security and have responded. It is vital that Australia responds in a similar manner.

We, the petitioners, therefore request that a set of national regulations similar to the EU's GDPR and ePrivacy regulation be enforced on all organisations operating in Australia in order to protect our peoples. These regulations focus on providing digital rights to citizens, including but not limited to: The right to be informed The right of access The right to rectification The right to erasure The right to restrict processing The right to data portability The right to object Rights in relation to automated decision making and profiling. There is also focus on the importance of citizens being secure by default. Furthermore, we believe it is critical that these regulations are developed by an independent panel of privacy and security experts in order to ensure these goals are properly met.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN0618)
Live Animal Exports

Australia is the largest live animal exporter in the world. We not only participate in the in the mistreatment of animals, we lead the entire industry. As a citizen of this country, I feel ashamed of this. According to the public database of live animal exportation released by the Australian Government, 2,778,295 live animals were exported in terrible conditions in 2017 alone. Even worse, the mortality rate of live animals that are exported is currently 3.76%, on ships full of tens of thousands this means of animals hundreds of animals can die in transit. According to the Australian Position Statement on the Export of Livestock released in April 2011, on average, cattle are permitted under a metre of space on the transportation vessel per cow, and this space is even smaller for sheep. Majority of animals that are exported are slaughtered upon their arrival at their destination, yet we still insist on putting these animals through torture before that happens.
We therefore ask the House to update the Australian Position Statement on the Export of Livestock to include stricter rules on the treatment of animals while on board transportation vessels.
from 63 citizens (Petition No. EN0619)
Sentsov, Mr Oleg

This petition draws to the attention of the House to a political prisoner Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian film maker serving 20 years prison sentence in the Russian Federation and currently under an indefinite hunger strike. Oleg Sentsov was arrested on trumped-up terrorism charges by Russian authorities in the spring 2014 in Crimea. The entire case against him was based on the testimony of two supposed witnesses, one of whom subsequently recanted his initial statement as made under tortures. Sentsov also stated that he was tortured during the investigation of his deal. Sentsov is considered to be a political prisoner by the Human Right Centre Memorial, Amnesty International, PEN International, and other organization. On May 14, Sentsov started an infinite hunger strike demanding to free all Ukrainian political prisoners in Russia. This put his health and the same life in serious danger. Statements in support of Oleg Sentsov during his hunger strike were made by the Spokesperson of the European External Action Service, International PEN organizations of writers, European intellectuals and politics, and more. The issue was raised during the French President Emmanuel Macron visit to St Petersburg on May 26. Still, Oleg Sentsov continues a hunger strike, and no information about his health condition is available.
We therefore ask the House to: raise a Sentsov's case in the Australian Parliament and for the sake of the human rights to address state diplomatic channels in support of Oleg Sentsov.
from 139 citizens (Petition No. EN0620)
Education: Auslan

I recently formed a bond with my friends 16 yo aboriginal son, Jack who is completely deaf. Recently I have also become aware that there is only one Deaf Councillor servicing the entire NSW area. Upon my researching statistics I have also learnt 1 in 6 people have a hearing impairment and by 2050 1in 4 people will have a hearing impairment. 90% of babies are born with a hearing impairment are born to hearing parents. There are currently 30,000 completely deaf Australians who already use the Auslan Language. I think it is time deliver equal rights to the Deaf community by addressing the skills shortage that is obviously apparent.

We therefore ask the house to act by introducing Auslan into the school curriculum. To be studied on a mandatory basis from Kindergarten right through to year 10 & by choice in year 11 & 12. Thank You.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN0624)
Taxation

The current PAYG and company tax system in Australia is complicated and expensive to comply with, and god help anyone who is without resources who gets it wrong! It is seemingly full of "loop-holes". Everyone complains about the system and its fairness. It has a lot of drawbacks and, apparently, little support. This legislation should be repealed and replaced with a flat tax, minus all of the options for individuals and business to minimise their taxable income. So, no laws to reduce tax by moving money offshore or through negative gearing. A tax-free threshold could still be implemented under a flat tax system for individuals and businesses with insufficient resources. My request focusses on providing government with the taxes it needs to do its job, while avoiding the polarisation associated with tax related politics. It would also act as an additional incentive for government to implement policies that are positive for the economy and avoiding economically harmful policies.

I request the House repeal all PAYG and company tax legislation and replace it with a new flat tax of 15-20%. A "tax-free threshold" kept in line with the average annual wage could be used for individuals. The business tax-free threshold would apply to small business. The new legislation should not provide a mechanism to reduce taxable income. This flat tax would simplify the tax system and remove the politics, while ensuring the government is resourced adequately and is incentivised to implement good economic policies.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN0625)
Environment: Pharmaceuticals

"The open scientific literature demonstrates that pharmaceuticals enter the environment and can produce adverse effects.", (Kuster A, Adler N. 2014). A study by Yasmin Guler, Alex T. Ford. (Anti-depressants make amphipods see the light. Aquatic Toxicology, 2010) highlighted "the potential for highly prescribed anti-depressant drugs to change the behaviour of an ecologically relevant marine species in ways which could conceivably lead to population level effects." "Antibiotics can enter the environment via wastewater treatment plants and even a low concentration can cause harmless bacteria to pass resistance genes to pathogenic ones.", (Environmental Science & Technology 49(9), 5336-5345). In 2016, Environmental Science & Technology Letters published water analysis data from 59 small US streams noting that in the water there were 108 pharmaceuticals, one river contained 45 different drugs. The study states "interactive effects of complex mixtures of bioactive contaminants are global environmental-health priorities".

We ask the House to please provide government's view on: any assessments of the environmental impacts of pharmaceuticals in Australia; requiring pharmaceutical companies to provide estimates on the environmental impacts of pharmaceuticals in Australia; implementing environmental safety measures to reduce pharmaceutical pollution at source; methods required (cost of and who would pay) for detecting, monitoring and controlling the presence of pharmaceuticals in our environment including any in our drinking water, wildlife and aquatic spheres.
from 8 citizens (Petition No. EN0628)
Child Support Act

Single parent families are a growing family type in Australia: as such, ensuring a fair system is in place which ensures the best interests of children must be of paramount concern. The current Child Support Act is encouraging some parents to withhold children from their other parent (parental alienation) and does not reflect societies belief that all children deserve a meaningful relationship with both parents. The current act seeks to ensure that the main care-giving parent receives extra support if the other parent is choosing not to see their child however it is not applied in reverse to ensure that the main care-giver does not withhold the child and receive extra support. Currently, a below regular care determination can be made despite a parent wanting to see their child and being denied that right without cause. There is no onus placed on the main care-giver to negotiate a parenting plan. Currently if this situation exists timely and costly court proceedings are the only option for the alienated parent. For some parents who have teenage children, court action is unlikely to be viable due to the time delays in the courts. This results in a parent not only not being able to see their child but also being effected financially also. This is crippling to that parent.
We therefor ask the house to amend The Child Support Act to ensure that a parent is not financially rewarded for refusing to negotiate a parenting plan and encouraging contact with the other parent.
from 356 citizens (Petition No. EN0630)
Migration

Requesting that the House amend Social Services Legislation Amendment (Encouraging Self-sufficiency for Newly Arrived Migrants) Bill 2018. The proposed extension to Newly arrived resident's waiting period (NAWRP) is unfair. The current change suggests that all people who gain permanent residency after July 2018 will have to wait 4 years before they can access most benefits. These include individuals who have applied for their permanent residency last year and are waiting for their grant and if they were to receive their grant after Jul 2018 for no fault of theirs (longer processing times) they wouldn't be receiving these vital benefits. Through the current bill the applicants of permanent residency are put to the mercy of case officers which should not be the case. Furthermore there are other people who have been in Australia for more than 5-8 years and will be eligible for permanent residency in near future but they too will be deprived of these benefits even though they have spent a major part of their life in Australia contributing towards the welfare of the nation.

We therefore request the house to make following amendment to the Bill: The Newly arrived resident's waiting period (NAWRP) should be only applied to people who are arriving in Australia on any visa after Jul 2018 and it shouldn't be applicable to any current resident who is already residing in Australia legally whether he or she is a permanent resident or not.
from 72 citizens (Petition No. EN0634)
Child Abuse

BRAXTON'S LAW: Mandatory Registration of all child protection workers both government and private sector. Ensure the governing body is independent and external of government, so they have the power to investigate individual case complaints made by employees, carers, families and vulnerable children to enforce accountability at the frontline. Innocent Braxton Slager died needlessly from neglect after 3 weeks in care in 2014. His case manager had just 3 days internal training to manage his case and those of other children while employed as an administration officer. Details of Braxton's Story: https://www.facebook.com/braxtonnicholasslager/ Many children have died, disappeared, and are being neglected and abused daily nationwide. The main cause of failure in child protection is and always has been the lack of external accountability. The only way to save our vulnerable children is to enforce external accountability through Mandatory Registration as other Western Nations have for their child protection workers and as all other professions in Australia have to protect the public from harm. Child protection workers have more power than any other profession but are not registered or held externally accountable. No one is protected from the harm, often lifelong they cause particularly to children daily. Braxton's Law is recommendations 27 from the Federal Senate Community Affairs Committee 2014 Inquiry into Children in OOHC and has still not been acted on. It should not be the public calling for Mandatory Registration of all child protection workers this is role job of responsible government.
We ask the House to Implement BRAXTON'S LAW
from 388 citizens (Petition No. EN0641)
Electric Vehicles

Although as per legislation a wattage of over 200W is considered a Motor Vehicle, Electric Kick scooters that have a 250-watt motor are far from being a motor vehicle as they're a simple kick scooter with a small 250-watt motor at the rear with a one charge range of 25km. The motor is only this large to push a 60 - 100kg person along sufficiently 200 watts is not powerful enough. All Scooters come with a pre-set speed limit of 10km p/h as per the legal requirements. Inokim Electric Scooters are an eco-friendly alternative to personal travel, ideal for travelling in the inner city, and suburban areas. This mode of transport is a cost-effective alternative for the traveller.

We request the House to amend the Motor Vehicles Legislation (Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 (MVSA) legislation), to allow push/kick Scooters with an output Wattage of over 200W to 250 watts or more. If an amendment was granted it would allow the scooters to be used on public bike-ways and bring our states and country closer to our goals by reducing our carbon footprint, pollution, reduce cars on the roads and it's a fun safe way to travel! I ask the wattage to be increased by 50 watt to a capacity of 250 watts allowing for importation into Australia and usage on public bikeways and paths legally.
from 48 citizens (Petition No. EN0648)
Exotic Animals

As a person who lives in rentals, large pets are hard to rent with. You have slim options of housing because not all houses can accommodate pets. A landlord can outright refuse to let an uncontained animal on their property, so we are left with slim options. Some people need a companion that can help with stress and loneliness. Pets have many benefits for those suffering mental illnesses such as depression. We do have rabbits and guinea pigs, but they are still too big, and are more of an outside pet compared to something like a hedgehog, which is considered an indoor pet. These pets should be licensed but not outright illegal, as a license would mean that they are living with someone who could take responsibility for their companion and know enough about them to treat them well. When they are properly monitored, registered, and distributed, there would only a negligible risk of Zoonotic diseases or release of animals into the wild. Myself, and many Australians living in small rentals and apartments would be much happier to have the option to have a small, lovely companion to live with. To have the option to own a pet that doesn't make a mess of your home compared to having nothing at all would be great for both landlords and those renting
To make more small "exotic" animals legal as Australia has a limited options for small pets. For example Hedgehogs are very common small pets in America, England, and Japan.
from 37 citizens (Petition No. EN0649)
Taxation

The Catholic Churches highest representatives in Australia have publicly declared that their organisation will not obey state or federal laws regarding mandatory reporting of child abuse if they become aware of it through formal confession.

Request Australian Tax law be altered so that the Catholic Church and any other tax free status organisation in Australia that publically commits to refusing to follow any state or federal law (especially those that protect children) have their tax free status revoked.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN0650)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:04): I present the following ministerial responses to 12 petitions previously received:
Veterans
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2017 to the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon Dan Tehan MP, concerning petition number EN0325. The petition requests new laws to prescribe periods within which a delegate is required to make a decision in relation to DVA claims. I apologise for the delay in providing a response.

The Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission (MRCC) has previously considered the introduction of statutory timeframes in relation to determining initial liability claims. In June 2014, the MRCC released a report into the Review of Statutory Timeframes under the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA). A number of potential models were examined as part of this review.

The MRCC recommended that statutory timeframes not be applied to MRCA initial liability claims. It concluded that statutory timeframes would not produce better outcomes for claimants. In particular, the MRCC concluded there is a significant risk that statutory timeframes would result in poor, incomplete and incorrect outcomes for claimants.
The time in which an initial liability claim is finalised can be influenced by a number of factors including:
Whether the claim is complete;
The complexity of the claim;
Whether further evidence or information is required from the claimant, the Australian Defence Force, medical practitioners and specialists or other relevant third parties;

Determining the applicable legislation, as the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA), Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation (Defence-related Claims) Act 1988 (DRCA) and MRCA may all be applicable to the claim; and

The time between incident and lodgement of claim: if there has been a long period between the incident and claim further evidence or information may be required. All of the above factors may result in unavoidable delays in determining the initial liability claim.

While I acknowledge that statutory timeframes for determining initial liability claims may provide certainty to claimants, there is a significant risk that claims may be determined without consideration of the full merits of the case and result in inequitable outcomes among clients with similar circumstances. Determinations should be based on evidence, as per the legislative intent of the repatriation legislation, as opposed to timeframes.

The current process for determining claims is that, where possible, the investigation of all claims commences within seven days of a delegate being assigned the case, all follow up actions are completed on the day they become due and that delegates seek assistance immediately where difficulties or complexities in determining the claim arise.

The MRCC and the Repatriation Commission are committed to determining all claims for compensation in an accurate and timely manner. As part of this, the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) is undertaking a number of reform initiatives to improve the compensation claims process as well as communication and engagement with clients. These initiatives include:
MyService â online claims processing portal that streamlines and simplifies lodgement of claims;

"Decision-ready" processing for 40 medical conditions under the MRCA and the VEAâthese are conditions where a claim can be processed using the client's profile and known conditions of service to quickly determine whether a factor linking the condition with service has been met;
Improved processes for obtaining information from the Department of Defence; and
Improved communication and simplified ways of contacting OVA.

In the 2016-17 financial year, the mean and median times taken to process VEA compensation claims, DRCA liability claims and MRCA liability claims were all under the relevant targets for the financial year. Over the past four financial years, the mean time taken to process has decreased for DRCA and MRCA liability claims, and remained steady for VEA claims. A graph showing this data is enclosed. The Commission are continuing to undertake work to improve the time taken to process compensation claims, and reduce the time taken to process claims.
I trust that this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Chester(Petition No. EN0325)
Pesticides
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2018 referring petition EN0440 submitted to the Standing Committee on Petitions which seeks to ban pesticides in Australia. As the minister with portfolio responsibility for agricultural chemicals, I welcome the opportunity to respond to the petition.

As reflected in our robust regulatory systems, protecting human and environmental health is always the Australian Government's first priority and a ban of pesticides is not warranted. I recognise the considerable risks posed by the misuse of agricultural chemicals to the environment and human health. At the same time, where chemicals can be used safely, they enhance the productivity and competitiveness of our agricultural sector and protect our community and environment from pests and diseases.

Australia has a risk-based, efficient and robust regulatory framework for agricultural chemicals. Before agricultural chemicals can be legally sold, supplied or used in Australia, they must be evaluated and registered by the independent national regulator for agricultural chemicals, the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA).

The APVMA and its external advisory agencies scientifically assess the risks posed by new agricultural chemicals to ensure the health and safety of people, animals and the environment are protected, and to support international trade. The APVMA may also undertake a formal review of a registered agricultural chemical or product if new scientific information emerges suggesting a change in the risks to people, animals, the environment, or trade.

The states and territories are responsible for regulating and managing the use of agricultural chemical products once they are sold and ensuring that users comply with the APVMA-approved product instructions.
Thank you again for referring this petition to me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Agriculture and Water Resources, MrLittleproud(Petition No. EN0440)
Department of Veterans' Affairs
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 March 2018 about petition number EN0451.

The Government does not support a Royal Commission into the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA), as there's already been a number of significant, independent reviews conducted and several new reviews underway relating to suicide and mental health in the veteran community and the performance of the Department. Furthermore, DVA has listened to concerns from the veteran community about its programs and delivery of its services and is on a substantial journey of transformation to put veterans and their families first. This transformation will address DVA's business processes, client service, organisational culture and information and communications technology (ICT).
Previous Reviews

The report of the Defence, Foreign Affairs and Trade Senate Committee Inquiry into the Suicide by Veterans and Ex-Service Personnel, The Constant Battle: Suicide by Veterans comprehensively examined the issue of suicide in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and veteran community. This report made 24 recommendations. The Government accepted 22 recommendations and accepted two recommendations in principle. This inquiry was preceded by two other major reviews:
Defence, Foreign Affairs and Trade Senate Committee Inquiry into Mental Health of ADF Members and Veterans â the Government responded to this Inquiry report on 15 September 2016; and the

National Mental Health Commission Review of Suicide and Self-Harm Prevention Services Available to Current and Former Serving ADF Members and their Families (201617) which made 23 recommendations. The Government responded on 30 June 2017 setting out four target areas of focus â improving suicide prevention and mental health support, improving the transition process for ADF members, improving family support and transforming DVA.

Additionally, in response to the tragic death by suicide of a veteran, Mr Jesse Bird, on 27 June 2017 the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Dan Tehan MP, requested a joint inquiry by DVA and the Department of Defence and the Veterans and Veterans Families Counselling Service into the management of Jesse Bird's case. Nineteen recommendations were made by the inquiry with a focus on improvement of the service and experience of veterans seeking compensation and support. These recommendations were released publicly by the then Minister. Changes have been made to DVA policies, client service, processes and systems to address the recommendations. An independent review will be conducted later this year into the Department's implementation of these recommendations.
In response to the Jesse Bird joint inquiry and the 2017 Senate Inquiry report, the Government announced on 24 October 2017 a $31 million package covering five measures:
$16.1 million over four years for a new Veteran Payment for veterans with mental health conditions - commenced 1 May 2018;
$7.1 million over four years to extend support to families of veterans - commenced 1 May 2018;
$2.1 million over four years for an annual health assessment for ex-serving ADF members for the first five years post-discharge â starting 1 July 2019;
$4 million over two years to pilot a case management service for transitioning ADF members or veterans who enter a crisis â staring 1 July 2018; and
$1.7 million over one year to undertake the scoping study mentioned above to professionalise veterans' advocacy â commenced April 2018 and due to report late 2018.
Legislation to support the first two of these measures was passed by Parliament on 28 March 2018.
New Reviews/inquiries

Of the 22 recommendations of the 2017 Senate Inquiry report, 13 call for further reviews, scoping studies or trials. A number of the recommended reviews have commenced. The most significant of these are:

the Productivity Commission has been commissioned to inquire into: whether the system of veterans' rehabilitation and compensation is fit for purpose now and into the future along with the Departments' governance arrangements, administrative processes and service delivery. This inquiry was announced on 28 March 2018 and is under way. It will report by June 2019 and involves public consultation through submissions and public hearings;

the Australian National Audit Office is undertaking a performance audit on "Efficiency of veterans' service delivery by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA)". This audit called for public submissions by 31 March 2018 and is expected to report in June 2018; and

a scoping study of veterans' advocacy and representation is being conducted by Mr Robert Cornall AO. This was announced on 16 April 2018 and is due to report by late 2018. This involves public submissions and consultation.

In addition, several other specific reviews/studies are underway in response to the Senate inquiry recommendations. These cover such issues as: the mental health impacts of the compensation claim assessment process; veteran-specific online training programs for health professionals; DVA training programs for its staff; DVA's use of medico-legal firms for compensation claims assessment; and DVA's engagement of younger veterans through social media.
DVA's Transformation

In the 2016-17 Budget, the Government provided $23.9 million over two years to enable OVA to upgrade its ICT for rehabilitation and compensation claims processing. In the last two years DVA has been progressively building new ICT capacity for this processing and this capability has already had an impact in reducing processing times and improving the quality of decision-making and communication with clients.

In the 2017-18 Budget, the Government allocated $166.6 million over four years as a first tranche of funding towards DVA's transformation journey â transforming DVA into a more connected, client-focussed organisation responsive to the needs of the veteran community. Veterans and their families will benefit from a better experience dealing with OVA and improved programs of support. The first year has been focussed on delivering more modern technology foundations for DVA's new ICT infrastructure and establishing new DVA service capabilities. Already a number of new service concepts have benefitted the veteran community. DVA's transformation has been informed by considerable program of engagement, communication and co-design with the veteran community. This has enhanced DVA's understanding of its areas of client service delivery needing improvement and the new programs and services required to meet the needs and expectations of the veteran community.

In the 2018-19 Budget, the Government has continued to invest in DVA's transformation journey with a further $111.9 million over four years to build on the foundations laid in 2017-18. This represents a substantial financial commitment by Government to transform OVA to provide a more modern and client-centric service to veterans, their families and the broader community.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Chester(Petition No. EN0451)
Taxation
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 March 2018 concerning Luxury Car Tax (LCT). I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The Government is not currently considering removing the LCT, which has existed in one form or another for many years, Prior to its introduction in 2000 as part of the goods and services tax (GST) changes, luxury cars were taxed at the standard rate of wholesale sales tax plus a higher rate above the luxury threshold.

The purpose of the LCT was to ensure that when the GST was introduced, the price of luxury cars did not fall disproportionately more than the price of standard cars. The LCT originally applied at a rate of 25 per cent of the value of the luxury cars above the LCT threshold. The rate was increased to 33 per cent (the current rate) in 2008.

In acknowledgement that fuel-efficient cars have a lower environmental impact, legislation was passed in 2008 to distinguish the LCT treatment of fuel-efficient cars from other cars. For this reason, the LCT threshold is $65,094 for ordinary cars, and $75,526 for fuel-efficient cars. This distinction in the application of the LCT is designed to encourage the purchase of fuel-efficient cars.
The Australian Government uses the revenue from the LCT to fund essential services that all Australians benefit from such as health, education, defence and security.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Morrison(Petition No. EN0472)
Taxation
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 March 2018 concerning removing the Goods and Services Tax (GST) on feminine hygiene products. The Government understands the application of the GST to feminine hygiene products is an important issue for many people. I sincerely apology for the delay in responding to you.

The GST is a broad-based tax of 10 per cent on most goods, services and other items sold or consumed in Australia. Limited exemptions were included where imposing the CST would be technically difficult, create inequities between private and public sector providers, or necessary to secure the passage of the GST legislation through the Senate.

Under the Intergovernmental Agreement on Federal Financial Relations and Commonwealth legislation, a change to the GST rate or base would need the unanimous support of the States and Territories. At the August 2015 Council on Federal Financial Relations Tax Reform Workshop, former Treasurer Joe Hockey raised the issue of feminine hygiene products with the States and Territories. As no unanimous agreement was reached, no changes to the existing GST arrangements were progressed.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Morrison(Petition No. EN0478)
Parliamentary Petitions
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for forwarding to me for a response a petition received by the Petitions Committee requesting that petitions receiving more than a threshold number of petitioners be scheduled for debate in the House of Representatives as well as being responded to by an appropriate Minister.

As you and the Committee would be aware, the United Kingdom House of Commons has arrangements to enable debate on petitions in certain circumstances. The request in the petition would, in my view, require standing orders to be amended. As you would be aware, formal proposals to amend the standing orders of the House are a matter for the House to consider, usually at the initiative of the Leader of the House. On this basis, I suggest it would be appropriate for you to direct this petition to the Leader of the House, the Hon Christopher Pyne MP. The Leader of the House may then choose to consult the Clerk if he wishes to propose an amendment to the standing orders.

I note that the Committee in recommendation 3 of its recent report, 'Making voices heard', indicated an intention to inquire into the petitions system and consider processes in other jurisdictions. The subject of the request in the petition might well form part of the Committee's considerations in the future.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker, Mr Smith(Petition No. EN0503)
Commonwealth Coat of Arms
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter to the Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, dated 21 May 2018, enclosing petition EN0505, which requests that the Australian Government act to add the Crown Insignia to the Crest of the Commonwealth Coat of Arms. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf as the Minister responsible for national symbols policy.

King Edward VII made the first official grant of a Coat of Arms to the newly formed Commonwealth of Australia on 7 May 1908. The first Coat of Arms showed the kangaroo and emu supporting the shield and standing on a grassy mound. The shield displayed the cross of St George. King George V made Australia's second grant of arms in a Royal Warrant dated 19 September 1912. The significant change was to include the symbols of the states on the shield. The petitioner may be interested to know that the shield includes two images of the Imperial Crown, as seen in the symbols for Victoria and Queensland.
The Government has no plans to request a change to the current version of the Coat of Arms. Thank you for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Senator McGrath(Petition No. EN0505)
Macedonia
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 21 May 2018 regarding petition EN0512 to the Standing Committee on Petitions, requesting Australia retain its policy on the nomenclature of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (fYROM).

The Australian Government continues to use the nomenclature 'former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia' in all bilateral and multilateral interactions with the country. Australia's policy strives to be impartial by using the terminology agreed to in the United Nations by the parties to the dispute. This is a temporary measure pending a mutually agreed solution by the governments in Athens and Skopje.

The Australian Government has been encouraged by the announcement on 12 June 2018 by Prime Ministers Tsipras and Zaev that an agreement had been reached to recognise the name 'Republic of North Macedonia'. We encourage the governments in Athens and Skopje to continue to work constructively together to resolve this long-standing issue.
The Australian Government will review its policy on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia nomenclature when the governments in Athens and Skopje advise they have formally adopted a new name.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop(Petition No. EN0512)
Macedonia
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 21 May 2018 regarding petition EN0525 requesting Australia change its policy on the nomenclature of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

The Australian Government remains mindful of the sensitivity and the depth of feeling, including in communities in Australia, regarding Australia's use of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia nomenclature. Australia's policy follows the UN practice of using the terminology 'former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia' until such time as a mutually agreed solution is achieved.

The Government has been encouraged by the announcement on 12 June 2018 by Prime Ministers Tsipras and Zaev that an agreement had been reached to recognise the name 'Republic of North Macedonia'. We encourage the governments in Athens and Skopje to continue to work constructively together to resolve this long-standing issue.
The Government will review its policy on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia nomenclature when the governments in Athens and Skopje advise they have formally adopted a new name.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop(Petition No. EN0525)
Foreign Aid Grants
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 21 May 2018 regarding petition number EN0531 on the Foreign Aid Budget.

Australia's development assistance must meet the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's (OECD) Development Advisory Committee (DAC) Official Development Assistance (ODA) eligibility criteria for it to be included within the Australian aid budget. The activities outlined in your petition do not meet OECD DAC ODA eligibility requirements and therefore could not be included within the Australian aid budget.

Australia's development assistance contributes to sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction, especially in the Indo-Pacific. This both supports the strong and direct national interest we have in stability and prosperity in our region and reflects our values as a nation.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop(Petition No. EN0531)
South Africa
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 21 May 2018 enclosing Petition number: EN0535, concerning visa applications made by South African nationals to emigrate to Australia, that was presented in the House of Representatives on 21 May 2018.

Australia's Humanitarian Programme is a non-discriminatory programme designed primarily to assist people who have left their home country because of persecution or severe human rights abuses, and who have no options for return or for resettlement in another country. Resettlement places may also be available for people subject to persecution who have remained in their home country.

Any person who believes they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. Each application is considered on its individual merit using current and comprehensive information on circumstances in the relevant country.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton(Petition No. EN0535)
Rohingya
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 21 May 2018 regarding Petition Number PN0344 on Rohingya refugees from Myanmar.

The Australian Government shares the concerns raised in the petition about the situation of the Rohingya. The Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, and I, have made a number of representations to Her Excellency State Counsellor Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, including during her visit to Australia in March 2018.

Australia is a long-standing development partner of Myanmar. Through our aid program, we continue to promote peace and stability, strengthen democratic institutions, deliver humanitarian assistance, improve access to quality education, and promote inclusive economic growth.

A stable and prosperous Myanmar is important for the stability and security of our region. Myanmar remains at a critical stage of democratic and economic transition, with significant development and humanitarian needs. Our view is continuing constructive, carefully targeted engagement is the best Way to make a real difference to the lives of all Myanmar people.

The Prime Minister and I jointly announced increased humanitarian funding of $15 million to the Rohingya Crisis in Bangladesh on 28 April 2018. I announced an additional $13 million in humanitarian assistance to Myanmar on 4 May 2018, of which $5 million is addressing the needs of Rohingya in Rakhine State. Australia has provided a total of $51.5 million in humanitarian assistance to the Rohingya Crisis in Bangladesh and Myanmar since September 2017.

The Australian Government condemns the human rights violations that have occurred. Australia has supported efforts to highlight the plight of the Rohingya in international forums, including the UN Human Rights Council (HRC), and will continue to do so.

Australia has supported multiple resolutions at the HRC and the UN General Assembly calling for an end to violence, unfettered humanitarian access, and the right of displaced Rohingya to return to Myanmar in a safe, voluntary and dignified manner. We repeatedly call for perpetrators of abuses to be held to account, and support the UN Fact Finding Mission on Myanmar.

Australia continues to encourage the Myanmar Government to create the conditions for the safe return of displaced Rohingya, including through implementation of the recommendations of the Advisory Commission on Rakhine State led by Kofi Annan.

The signing of a Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of Myanmar and the United Nations (UNDP and UNHCR), on 6 June 2018, is a positive first step. It will aim to establish a framework of cooperation towards creating conditions conducive to the voluntary, safe, dignified and sustainable repatriation of displaced Rohingya.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop(Petition No. PN0344)
PETITIONS
Statements

Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:04): Of the 17 petitions I present to the House today, sixteen are e-petitions. In total 309 e-petitions have now been presented to the House during the 45th Parliament, either by myself as Chair of the Petitions Committee or by individual members of the House. In contrast, 273 paper petitions have been presented to the House during this parliament.

These numbers continue to show how e-petitioning has successfully engaged Australians in petitioning the House. The committee reflected on the first years of e-petitioning during its recent inquiry into the House e-petitioning system. After hearing directly from users and learning from the experience of other parliaments, the committee recommended a number of enhancements to further simplify the e-petitioning process and improve the user experience. The committee hopes these improvements will see even more Australians create, sign and share e-petitions on matters of concern to them.
I look forward to updating the House further on the work of the Petitions Committee and as enhancements to the e-petitions system are progressed.
BUSINESS
Rearrangement
Mr WILKIE (Denison) (10:05): At the request of the member for Kennedy, I fix Monday, 10 September 2018 as the day for presenting the Inland Rail Project (Improving Accountability) Bill 2018.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Fair Work Amendment (Restoring Penalty Rates) Bill 2018

p.span: Fair Work Amendment (Restoring Penalty Rates) Bill 2018
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Ms OWENS (Parramatta) (10:06): I'm very proud to stand to support the Fair Work Amendment (Restoring Penalty Rates) Bill, because we on this side of the House understand just how much pressure families are under. Cost-of-living pressures and the cost of rent in my area of Parramatta are dramatically impacting on households' capacity to pay their bills. I know how many families in my area trying to balance their work, family and cost-of-living issues have sorted out ways to get through their lives by working a few extra shifts on the weekend, with maybe one partner working a few extra days. That is incredibly important to the decisions they have made about how they fund their families and pay the bills. And this decision by the Fair Work Commission and the decision by this Turnbull government to enthusiastically support that decision show just how out of touch this government is. It shows a complete lack of understanding of how much pressure households are under from the costs of living and stagnant wage growth, let alone wage cuts. It's also bad economics. It was at the time and it has been proven to be so since it was introduced.

Let's look at the impact on families first. Let's look at who's hit and who suffers the most. Low-paid workers in retail, fast food, hospitality and pharmacy have had their penalty rates cut and, when it flows through finally, will be up to $3,273 worse off a year. That's a $70 cut for a Sunday penalty shift. Calculations show that, because of the cuts to Sunday and public holiday penalty rates, workers in various industries face cuts to take-home pay up to the following amounts: pharmacy, $3,273; retail, $2,450; hospitality, $1,884; fast food, $1,628; and restaurants, $586. The government can afford to give $7,000 tax cuts to people on $200,000 a year, while taking away penalty rates from the people who can least afford it. In Parramatta, there are 12,300 people or one in six workers in the retail, food and accommodation industries affected by the cuts to penalty rates. That's one in six. In Parramatta, we're seeing up to one in six workers losing up to $77 a week as well as an additional $80 a week on new tolls, rents well over $400 a week and a new Medicare levy coming in for lower income workers. The government, of course, thinks it can compensate people with a $10 a week tax cut for what are substantial decreases in their take-home pay. But it's not just about the families that are affected. These are actually customers. One in six customers in Parramatta have had their take-home pay cut, and these are the lowest paid people in our community who spend every dollar they earn. If you cut the wages of one in six of your customers, what do you think you get? You get less spending for a start. That, to me, is so obvious. When we have been debating this for over a year now, I've been wondering why those on the other side who claim to know so much about business don't get what happens when one in six of your customers get their take-home pay cut, particularly if those customers are the ones that spend all the money.

The figures prove the point. A survey of 1,351 workers by the University of Wollongong and Macquarie University found 'there has been no short-term increase in the number of hours worked by employees'. The government promised that, if they cut penalty rates, there would be more jobs and more hours. There are not. University of Wollongong lecturer Martin O'Brien is reported as saying:
â¦ some workers experienced a drop in the number of penalty-rate hours they worked in the first two months after penalty rates were reduced.
They concluded:
â¦ 15 per cent of all retail workers who were employed on Sundays worked 9 per cent fewer hours, while hospitality workers experienced no change.
So retail workers actually worked fewer hours.

It was also obvious that the cuts would impact on consumer spending. All those penalty rate workers that dropped into the pub on the way home from work before their penalty rates were cut just don't do it now. They just don't do it. They have less money in their pockets to spend in local businesses. The controversial cuts to Sunday and public holiday rates on 1 July were followed by the weakest three months of consumer spending since the global financial crisis. So consumer spending was at zero growth following the cuts to penalty rates.

All the promises about the positive benefits of cuts to penalty rates have not been forthcoming, but damage to the income of households has. We have families increasingly struggling to pay the bills and looking at subsequent penalty rate cuts over the next few years. It's bad policy from the government, and I support this amendment to wind it back.

Mr LAUNDY (ReidâMinister for Small and Family Business, the Workplace and Deregulation) (10:11): I rise today to continue to discuss the hypocrisy of those opposite when it comes to penalty rates. For over 100 years now, rates of pay in this country have been set independent of government. The reason for that was in case you ever had a situation where a populist leader, desperate to do anything to become Prime Minister, turned around and promised a pay increase in an attempt to get votes. Heaven help us that that's exactly where we find ourselves today. The even greater irony is that the independent umpire in its current form was in fact put in place and overseen by the Labor Party and the union movement, post the 2007 election: the Fair Work Commission, which is the independent umpire in all things to do with industrial relations.

The irony doesn't stop and the hypocrisy doesn't stop there. The Leader of the Opposition was one of the key architects of that act, where the four-yearly reviews of modern awards were initiated, the process that came up with the decision that we're debating today. There was hypocrisy again in 2010, when the Leader of the Opposition was the minister responsible, when there was the first decision by the Fair Work Commission to reduce penalty rates in some modern awards. What did we hear from those opposite? Crickets. We heard nothing. Then in 2014, at the end of another four-yearly review, there were more changes to reduce Sunday penalty rates to some restaurant awards. And what did we hear then? We finally heard support for the Fair Work Commission, especially, most loudly, from the member for Gorton, the shadow minister, who stood up and argued that that is how the system works and the Fair Work Commission is the independent umpire, as it should be, as is fit and proper. But the even bigger hypocrisy here, the latest example, is that those opposite today are saying that they will turn around and overrule their own independent umpire, the Fair Work Commissionâthe one that they constructed.

The bill that we're talking about, the Fair Work Amendment (Restoring Penalty Rates) Bill 2018, does not include changes to enterprise bargaining agreements. But the reality is that the Leader of the Opposition, in his union career pre politics, did exactly what he is rallying against today. In 2006, in an agreement that he oversaw, 780 BigW workers in North Queensland had their Sunday penalty rates cut from 200 per cent to 150 per cent. In another 2006 agreement, again under his stewardship, 129 Target workers in North Queensland had their penalty rates cut from 200 per cent to 150 per cent.

Before the last election, when the member for Maribyrnong, the Leader of the Opposition, was asked by Neil Mitchell on 3AW if he would accept the findings of the independent umpire and the decision about penalty rates that was pending at that stage, he answered yes. Neil Mitchell asked:
You'll accept them?
SHORTEN: Yes
MITCHELL: Even if they reduce Sunday penalty rates?
SHORTEN: Well, I said I'd accept the independent tribunal â¦

It suited him then; it doesn't suit him now. Why? Because he's in a populist drive for votes. At the same time, as I mentioned, there is the hypocrisy. I ran into a young bloke, Michael, in my electorate working in a major fast-food chain a couple of weekends ago, on a Saturday. I asked him what roster he works. He works six hours on a Saturday and six hours on a Sunday. He is $27 a week worse off because he is employed under an enterprise bargaining agreement that was negotiated by the shop, distributive and allied union, the SDAâthe biggest supporter of the Labor Party in terms of both membership and dollars over the last decadeâwhich has actually reduced penalty rates far in excess of what the Fair Work Commission has come up with, after taking hundreds of submissions on the topic across all players in the industry and considering the case on its merits.

Michael is in year 10 in my electorate. You've got predominantly young schoolkids and university students in these major retail chainsâmultinational in some cases, but national in all casesâthat are subject to enterprise bargaining agreements that have deductions that are well in excess of what we are talking about the Fair Work Commission making. It is hypocrisy writ large. Today is just the latest example of that. If the Leader of the Opposition tells you it's raining, I'd advise those in Australia to stick their head outside and have a look.

Mr PERRETT (MoretonâOpposition Whip) (10:16): I rise to speak on the Fair Work Amendment (Restoring Penalty Rates) Bill 2018. Before I do, in the absence of the shadow industrial relations minister, I'd like to pass on my condolences to Brendan and Una on the loss of their fabulous Jodi Dack at this sad time.

I speak on this bill, which was introduced by the Leader of the Opposition in June. Sadly, the government's agenda didn't include bringing this bill on for debate before the long winter recess. Clearly, they had other things on their mind, like trying to give an $80 billion tax cut to the big end of town. The take-home pay of working Australians was cut yet again on 1 July, again on this minister's watch, on the Turnbull government's watch. On 1 July, hardworking Australians who make sacrifices to work the hours when most of us are spending time with our families again had their take-home pay slashed. This time the cuts were even deeper.

At a time when workers are suffering the fall-out from wage stagnation and rising cost-of-living pressures, this heartless government has overseen more money leaving workers' pay packets. This mean-spirited government has done everything it can to undermine working Australians. More than 13,000 workers in my electorate of Moreton rely on penalty rates to put food on the table, to put petrol in their cars and to pay their rentâthat's one in six workers. Cutting penalty rates means my people will have to work longer hours for less pay. That is why Labor has introduced this bill to protect a principle as old as the Labor Party itself: a fair day's pay for a fair day's work.

There's nothing fair about the lowest-paid workers having their take-home pay cut. There's nothing fair about women, who already suffer from the gender pay gap, having their take-home pay cut. There's nothing fair about the economic policies that the Turnbull government believes in and continues to inflict on Australian workersâpolicies that will give corporate giants an $80 billion tax cut while cutting $17 billion from our schools and cutting $440 million from preschool education, which will see 350,000 Australian children miss out on preschool altogether.

The Medicare freeze has effectively already cut $3 billion from Australia's health care. Not protecting the penalty rates of Australian workers and cutting the take-home pay of the most vulnerable workers deepens inequality. On average, a woman earns $25,000 less each year than the average man and spends between five and 14 hours a week doing unpaid housework compared to fewer than five hours for men. Yet women make up the majority of employees in industries that will have their penalty rates cut, such as retail and hospitality. I would hope Minister Cash spoke up and knew about this when this cut came through on 1 July.

Vulnerable, low-paid workersâwomen and young people especiallyâare the people who will suffer most from these penalty rate cuts. The young university students who work weekends so they can attend their lectures during the week will be forced to make up extra hours to pay their way through university. Single mothers will have to spend more time away from their children just so they can put food on the table. You have to wonder about the priorities of the Turnbull government, which are prepared to cut the take-home pay of young people who are striving to make a greater contribution to Australia and of mothers who just want to give their children a good start in lifeâthis, while they are zealots about making sure their big corporate mates get a tax cut, including giving the banks $17 billion.

Tragically, cutting the penalty rates of people who earn low wages is also hurting the economy. Workers on low wages usually spend every cent they earn. They now have less to spend, starving the economy of much-needed expenditure; it's especially bad for retail and hospitality. On eight separate occasions in this parliament, this government has voted against protecting the penalty rates of vulnerable, low-paid workers. Eight times it has made it clear that it will not protect the wages of hardworking Australians. Labor will not sit back and do nothing. Labor will protect hardworking Australians, who are just trying to pay their bills. That's why the Leader of the Opposition, Bill Shorten, introduced this bill. It's a bill to stop the cuts to penalty rates and ensure that they can never be cut again. The Turnbull government did not bring this bill on for debate before 1 July. Why? Because it wanted Australian workers to get a pay cut.

Penalty rates are not a luxury for the 13,000 workers in my electorate of Moreton. Penalty rates put food on their tables and petrol in their cars and give them a chance in life. The Labor Party will always stand up for such workers. The Labor Party will always do the right thing. The fact is that the opposition leader has always stood up for workers. Despite the comments being made by those opposite, the opposition leader has a long track record of actually working to support working-class and middle-class Australiansâthose who want to get ahead. Labor will always stand up for those workers, and I will fight for penalty rates as long as I am here.

Mr TIM WILSON (Goldstein) (10:21): It's a great pleasure to get up and speak on the Fair Work Amendment (Restoring Penalty Rates) Bill 2018, because it's not often in this place, Mr Speaker, that you see an own goal being provided while it's in action. It's not a hole in one like the member for Shortland's new mini golf course but an own goal, where the opposition get up and move a motion, filled with impassioned speeches concerned about penalty rates so that they can load up onto Facebook and their social media accounts something that simply isn't occurring. Instead, what it does is provide an opportunity for the government to talk honestly about what is actually happening and shine some light onto the dishonest scare campaigns led by the opposition and particularly by the actions of the Leader of the Opposition, who has never shied away from an attemptâand the previous speaker was rightâto cut people's penalty rates, to cut their benefits and, even worse, while he takes money from them as a former union leader, to advance his own interests at their expense.

I actually happen to agree with the previous speaker on the point about penalty rates being necessary, particularly in disproportionately being to the benefit of young people who are seeking work, often when they're balancing out multiple workplaces or they're also studying, or women who may want flexibility in their workplace arrangements. But, of course, many Australians want flexibility in their workplace arrangements. These are exactly the people that the opposition leader has a long track record, and the Labor Party has a long track record, of selling out. We have the example in 2006 with the agreement for 780 Big W workers in North Queensland who had their penalty rates cut from 200 per cent under the award to 150 per cent under the wonderful leadership of the opposition leader and the Australian Workers' Union. We had the other 2006 agreement covering 129 Target workers in North Queensland who had their penalty rates cut from 200 per cent under the award to 150 per cent as well. Another example in a long line, a conga line, of secret deals done between the opposition leader as a trade union leader and big business to advance his interests at the expense of workers is the 2006 agreement covering 119 Just Jeans workers, who also had their penalty rates cut from 200 per cent under the award to 150 per cent. The result for all these workers was that they had $53 less pay in their pockets for a Sunday shift. What a proud record the Australian Labor Party has in defending the interests of workers!

There are many examples. The union has a long history of selling out its members and their interests by striking deals with big business to advance the interests of the apparatchiks who operate inside their unions and their political arm, which is, of course, the Australian Labor Party. These same workers have watched their penalty rates disappear under the Australian Workers' Union and are now watching the shallow morals of the Leader of the Opposition spread like a weed throughout the Labor Party. It's a cancerous infection that is now deep at the heart of the opposition, who don't care about workers and won't stand up for them but carry with them the legacy and track record of selling them out.

With this bill, the Leader of the Opposition is essentially asking the Fair Work Commission to act with the same inconsistency he has demonstrated day in, day out in his role as a leader of the union and also as the opposition leader sitting in this parliament. It might come as a surprise, but being opportunistic and untrustworthy are not character traits that should be emulated. Australians expect their leaders to act with integrity and, I might add, some consistency, which the opposition leader can claim no capacity to do. They also don't expect politicians to demoralise independent bodies like the Fair Work Commission purely for their political gain. The Fair Work Commission, as set up by Laborâlet us remind ourselves of thisâis required to ensure awards are fair and relevant, taking into account the impact on business employment costs and, of course, wanting to increase the number of jobs in the economy. That includes making evidence based adjustments to our award system that may involve corrections to take-home pay. You cannot expect the Fair Work Commission to perform its role if it loses the ability to deal with the different challenges affecting different workplace arrangements. There needs to be some flexibility to grow jobs for those people who are denied them. Both people and beliefs are disposable to the Leader of the Opposition and, as we've come to expect, if his lips are moving, you can't assume it's for anything other than self-opportunism.

Mr HART (Bass) (10:26): We've just received a contribution from the member for Goldstein which focused for five minutes not on the government's record with respect to looking after low-paid workers but simply on the Leader of the Opposition and his role as a leader of the union movement some time ago. This shows the total lack of policy direction from this government and, in effect, it shows just how out of touch the government is with low-paid workers in Australia at the moment.

I rise to support the Fair Work Amendment (Restoring Penalty Rates) Bill 2018. It's often said by commentators and indeed in this place that the news cycle, social media and political culture conspire to create a situation where arguments can be run, won and indeed lost in the space of hours, days or weeks on matters that seem to be of prime importance but, for those not engaged in politics, are of little consequence. If politics is the contest of ideas, those ideas should be about the issues that matter to the electorate. One side of politics may seek to promote its vision for Australia. Our responsibility as the opposition is to set up our alternative.

The contrast between the government's priorities and those reflected in this bill is significant. In fact, the contrast could not be more marked. This government has, at least in my view, a one-point plan, because that is all it has left. This one-point plan involves giving a tax cut to the largest corporations in Australia, including the big banks, in order to drive prosperity, championing the economics of trickle-down. Labor says that the revenue forgone through a tax cut for the big end of town could or should be spent on matters that deserve priorityâimportant priorities like our healthcare system, education and supporting the jobs of the future.

It's important to look at the immediate pressures upon Australian families. Australian voters know that this government cannot be trusted when it makes promises like savings on their power bills. Cost pressures are affecting ordinary Australians every day, and they need to see practical reliefânot trickle-down economics, not promises that this government's energy policy will see reductions in power bills and not promises of new employment driven by tax cuts but practical relief which is targeted at those who need it most.

The extraordinary thing is that this government, which claims a mantle of fiscal responsibility, should know that giving a tax cut to the largest corporations means that there is less money in the budget to pay for services that are important for ordinary Australians. They should know, because many economic commentators have been expressing their concern for many years that low wage growth is a significant risk for the Australian economy and threatens growth within the Australian economy, including employment growth, which also has the effect of depressing the amount of tax that will be collected from both personal and corporate income tax. In this setting the government needs to take responsibility for cuts to penalty ratesâcuts that affect the take-home pay of more than 700,000 Australian people and cuts that materially affect low-paid workers, students and people in the regions, including northern Tasmania, in which my electorate of Bass is based.

This government is quite properly criticised for being out of touch and failing to understand the pressures that have built up over many years due to low wage growth not keeping pace with cost-of-living increases. This government either doesn't care or simply ignores the fact that many low-paid workers will have suffered a reduction in their income, meaning there is less disposable income circulating within many communities. Small business relies upon customers that are able to access either disposable income, savings or borrowing. Any reduction in the disposable income of their customers will in turn affect those small businesses.

We hear no more about the potential for increased employment in hospitality or retail trade as a consequence of the reduction of weekend penalty rates. How many people really believe the promises that reduction in penalty rates would enable the employment of more staff? Even the government's much-vaunted job creation fails to recognise that wages growth overall is depressed, which in turn creates limitations upon economic growth. Underemployment continues to be a significant problem. People who are in insecure or part-time work are sustained by penalty rates. In some instances they organise their lives so that they are able to work on a Sunday so that they can receive extra income to sustain their families.

The spectre of rising inequality is something that should not be ignored by this government. Whilst the Treasurer insists that inequality is not a problem, economic commentators insist that increased inequality is again a restraint on this economy not just affecting those in insecure work and low-paid work but also limiting the opportunities of businesses to expand and the economy as a whole to grow in a more robust and sustainable manner. Only Labor has a plan to address the immediate concerns of workers that their wages will be cut.

Mr GOODENOUGH (Moore) (10:31): I have listened to the contributions of other members and wish to make the point that the commercial landscape, particularly in the areas of retail and hospitality services, has changed dramatically over the past decade. Retail trading hours have extended. Consumers demand more choice and flexibility in the hours during which they shop and access services. Competition has increased both domestically and from emerging economies in our region. In an increasingly global economy, costs have risen and margins have narrowed. Socially, we have changed as a nation as our nation has become more multicultural, with a diversity of customs. So, no longer is Sunday the universal day of rest that it once was, with different cultures observe Friday or Saturday as their preferred days of rest or those with busy lifestyles choosing to schedule their work and leisure commitments around study timetables or family commitments.

The contemporary Australian workplace must also adapt to these trends in order to stay relevant and competitive. In my electorate of Moore, retail businesses and those in the hospitality services sector make up a significant proportion of the local economy, with Hillarys marina being a major tourist destination, as well as a golf resort, major shopping centres, a bulk goods retail precinct and a service industrial area. Many businesses in my electorate are small to medium businesses, which are represented by the Joondalup Business Association. Our local business community is experiencing difficult times in the economic downturn and would like to extend trading hours to take advantage of the trend in consumers choosing to shop and dine at their convenience.
