When it comes to early years we are now seeing the impact of his so-called fix, with many families being pushed out of early learning, many kids denied the opportunity of access to high-quality early learning and the foundation for their school education and their journey through life. This is in defiance of the evidence and any principles of equity.

We all remember their triumph of just over a year ago and the false bravado of Minister Birmingham and of the government as a whole. They boasted that they had ended the schools funding wars. How does their boast look now? The government spoke of having ended Labor's 'special deals'. They are now flailing around whilst being internally divided, trying to stitch together deals to salvage their position. It is an extraordinary thing that Minister Birmingham has done in schools policy: he has offended every sector in the education system.

So we move on to universities. There is no fix here, because there is really no policy from the government. There is no meaningful policy after five years. That is in contrast to Labor's record of increasing investment in our universities and of recognising their critical role as an enabler of individual attainment of potential, of individual fulfilment in life, and as a driver of the sort of country we want to be, a country where we harness our greatest natural advantageâthe talents of young and older Australiansâto its fullest potential.

The government is in denial about that role of universities and about their critical role when it comes to research, supporting Australian businesses and investment more generally. We have seen more than $2 billion in cuts to universities. This is denying thousands of young Australians a place at university. It is impacting on the experiences of those currently at university. Over the break, I had the opportunity to speak with university students at the University of Melbourne and La Trobe University. The uncertainty that they face and feel for themselves and, indeed, for their younger brothers and sisters is palpable. It is a constraint on their opportunities and, again, on all of us.

We have this government here which once boasted, when the now Prime Minister took office, of agility and innovation. Yet its every action is to reverse of that. It is denying us the capacity to fulfil our potential by denying too many young Australians of their capacity to reach their potential. The government needs to understand the challenges of the workforce of the future.

We have just been involved in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on a significant bit of work around the transition from school. To make real the recommendations of that report, bipartisan recommendations, we need to do two things. We need to invest properly in our schools, but we also need to properly fund our universities and wrap that funding in a vision of a sustainable policy framework that looks to the first principles of our universitiesâtheir necessary role in enabling the higher education of talented young Australians, whatever their background, and their role as a driver of the research that is so critical to the future of the Australian economy. The government stands condemned for its neglect of Australia's universities and the cruel impact this has had and will continue to have. (Time expired)

Mr WALLACE (Fisher) (18:31): I'm grateful to the member for Griffith for proposing this motion as it gives us another opportunity to show up Labor's dishonesty and remind the people of Australia of the truth about university funding in Fisher and, indeed, all over the country. When I was at university, I studied law, and one of the things I learnt is how important it is to understand the words you are using and to use them with care. It's particularly important in our work here making the laws that govern Australians. A party that doesn't use words carefully is a party that doesn't deserve the people's trust.

Members opposite talk about cuts. They use the word 'cut's a lot. They throw it around. In fact, we have seen recently that repeating the word 'cuts' again and again is really all they have. Yet they seem, at best, to have no idea what that word means. This motion, and the whole of Labor's argument on education and health, is false, empty, meaningless, because it relies on a totally dishonest representation of this government's policy.

Let me offer members opposite some help. A quick look at a dictionary tells us that 'to cut' means 'to lower, reduce, diminish or curtail'. Perhaps they can begin to see how wrong they have beenâbecause the Turnbull government is not lowering university funding; it is, in fact, raising it. We are not reducing university funding, but increasing it. We are not diminishing or curtailing or lessening or decreasing university funding. We are growing it by 23 per cent over the next four years. An increase of billions of dollars is not a cut, not by anyone's honest definition, and the Australian people know it.

The Turnbull government is growing federal funding to universities to a record $17 billion this year. We will spend more on universities in each of the next four years than any federal government before, but we will contain that growth to responsible levels.

In my own electorate of Fisher, we have a fantastic regional universityâthe University of the Sunshine Coast. The USC is a dynamic, growing institution under the exceptional leadership of Vice-Chancellor Professor Greg Hill. I'm passionate about making the Sunshine Coast the place to be for education, and I've advocated strongly on behalf of USC in Canberra. I've worked closely with them since my election on projects like the federally funded Mind and Neuroscience Thompson Institute and on my Fisher defence industry initiative.

Through its rapid growth and it's well-earned success, USC has had the third largest increase in base funding for Commonwealth supported places of any university in the country since 2009. This funding continues to grow. Last year, funding for teaching and learning came to $165 million. This year it is $172 million, and it will keep growing to $182.8 million in 2021. This substantial federal support helped USC to a net operating result of $28.8 million in 2016 and to cash and investments of $79.9 million.

Under Vice-Chancellor Hill's leadership, USC is continuing to grow, with new campuses in Moreton Bay and Fraser Coast in Hervey Bay. For the new Moreton Bay campus, which I was delighted to be part of launching earlier this year, funding will increase by $69.4 million. Next year, this campus will get $7.5 million more. In 2020-21 it will receive $22.9 million in extra funding and in 2021-22 it will see an extra $39 million. We will also increase the number of Commonwealth supported places available to USC to fill that campus with new Australian students. USC's Moreton Bay campus will have 1,200 places in 2020, 2,400 places in 2021 and 3,600 places in 2022. We are further supporting this campus with a $35 million grant to the Moreton Bay Regional Council to build infrastructure.
There are no cuts here. The federal government is absolutely powering and empowering the university sector, particularly inâ (Time expired)

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (18:36): It saddens and infuriates but probably doesn't surprise me to hear the spin that those opposite are trying to put on these decisions. The government's latest effective cuts to university funding are hitting hardest those who can least afford it. In the electorate of Macquarie, which I represent, around 2,000 students attend Western Sydney University. Just before Christmas, the Turnbull government decided to freeze growth in university places as part ofâ

span.span: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 18:37
to

p.span: Ms TEMPLEMAN: Just before Christmas, the Turnbull government decided to freeze growth in university places as part of a fourth attempt at university cuts. At Western Sydney University, which many of my constituents attend, they're facing some of the largest hits to any university in New South Wales. Of the more than $2.2 billion being denied to universities across Australia, $93 million will not go to Western Sydney University. About a quarter of the students come from low-income families, and nearly 62 per cent of students at Western Sydney University are the first in their family to go to uni.

By slashing their funding, the government has effectively reintroduced limits on student numbers. There was no consultation and no discussion, just a big fat roadblock to someone's education. It takes us back to the bad old days when undergraduate places were determined by bureaucrats in Canberra. That led to a university system that wasn't keeping up with population growth or the needs of a growing economy. I remember when entry scores for courses were becoming high because supply was being deliberately held tight at a time of increasing demand. 'How dare people assume that they should be entitled to do go to universities!' seemed to be the prevailing idea. The reality of John Howard's university system was that many bright students were missing out on the course that they wanted, while others, who had wealthy parents, could buy their way into a course with a lower entry score by paying full fees. We can't go back to that. That skewed universities in favour of those from the most privileged backgrounds, while there was a lack of participation from students from outer metropolitan areas like mine. That's why Labor set about boosting participation in higher education, particularly the number of students from regional Australia and disadvantaged and unrepresented backgrounds. As a result, 190,000 more Australians have attended university, many coming from areas where participation was lower.

The university system should be driven by demand. It seems those opposite want to make it harder to go to uni, but we don't. Dr Andy Marks, who's the Assistant Vice-Chancellor of Western Sydney University, rightly asks:
How will freezing university enrolments in Western Sydney bring about the monumental skills-uplift required in the region's labour force?
How will demanding nurses, teachers and social workers pay more of their HECS debt sooner help deliver the frontline services the region so desperately needs?
The same dedicated people who already can't afford to live near where they work.

These are good questions and issues to raise. The consequences of the cuts are that students will be worse off, there will be fewer staff employed, scholarships will be at risk and some of the schemes that support not just students but the wider community will have to go.

Of course, not all the Blue Mountains and Hawkesbury based students go to Western Sydney University; many travel further afield to the University of Sydney, the University of New South Wales, Macquarie University, UTS and the University of Wollongong. That doesn't mean they're immune from these cuts. These cuts total $330 million over four years to those other New South Wales institutions.

Right now, many year-12 students are sitting their trial HSC in preparation for their main exams in October. Many of them have the added stress of making a decision about whether they go to university, which university to apply for and even whether or not they can really afford it. The students travelling from outer metropolitan areas, if they're lucky enough to get a place, will join the rest of Western Sydney in contending with the failing train system, hefty road tolls and long travel times, even if they're heading to a local campus. Others will opt for crazy rents and two-minute noodles in preference. Many will try and pay their way through uni on a wage that is less likely than ever to cover the cost of living, made worse by this government's attack on penalty rates. No matter which way you look at it, cutting funding to universities, especially those that impact Western Sydney, is yet another attack that will increase inequality. A Centre for Western Sydney report released last year shows bachelor degree attainment among young people in the region is 40 per cent lower than elsewhere. I'll quote Dr Marks again:
The government's freeze on funding shows they are OK with that imbalance.
Well, I see a problem. That imbalance is not okay with me.

Mr LEESER (Berowra) (18:55): I'm delighted to speak on this motion, which gives me an opportunity to highlight the deception that typifies the Shorten Labor Party. As we know, from its conception the Labor Party has been guided by a range of philosophersâfrom Marx to Engels and even Mark Latham. In more recent times, we know those opposite have been inspired by Jeremy Corbyn and Bernie Sanders. But, over the recess, I think I found their true guiding philosopher: Seinfeld's George Costanza. In fact, I've begun to wonder whether George Costanza's favourite maxim, 'It's not a lie if you believe it', was at some point surreptitiously inserted into the Labor Party's constitution. This Costanza-ite motion follows in the tradition of 'Mediscare' and 'Operation Tell Mistruths about Caboolture Hospital'. It's yet another embarrassing attempt to trick the voting public.

Labor seem to have conveniently forgotten their own party's record on higher education when they were in government. I encourage those opposite to reflect on the $6.6 billion in higher education and research cuts that Labor announced during its last three years in government, including $2.9 billion in its last budget in 2013-14. Yet in opposition Labor has opposed an efficiency dividend that it recommended while it was in government. University students and their families should know that Commonwealth university funding is not reducing, it's indeed growing.

The truth is that the Turnbull government is providing a record total of $17 billion per annum of investment in higher education. No-one is missing out on a university place this year or next year as a result of government policy. It is and remains, as it should, the universities' exclusive prerogative to enrol as many students as they wish. Universities receive the index student contribution from the Commonwealth for however many students they enrol. Funding of bachelor places is maintained at 2017 levels over the next two years. This doesn't affect how many students a university chooses to enrol.

The advantage of the demand driven funding model is that universities can choose which students they wish to enrol and how many students they will take. The Commonwealth provides funding on a per student basisâso the more students the more funding. The rate of funding per student has stayed the same. There is no cut. The reality is that, in the university sector, we want universities to be spending taxpayer money much more wisely than they're doing. There is a degree of fat in universities and we want to see more taxpayer money spent on academicsâteaching and researchâand less on back-office administrators. At the same time that Commonwealth funding per student has grown by 15 per cent, the costs for universities to deliver courses has only increased by 9Â½ per cent.

Independent analysis from Deloitte has shown that universities divert 15 per cent of taxpayer funding towards endeavours other than student and course related expenses, such as administration and marketing. We want to see more taxpayer money spent on teaching and research. The growth of funding that the Commonwealth has given to the university sector has outstripped the growth in the entire economy. Indeed, it's growing at twice the rate of the economy, and that just isn't sustainable. The truth is that Labor have had many opportunities to keep university funding on a sustainable basis but they would rather outdo the Greens on economic irresponsibility than fix the funding problems they created.

We need a long-term solution and that's why, under the Turnbull government's policy, from 2020 the growth of university funding will be based on population increases and will be subject to meeting performance measures. The old funding model was inefficient, wasting taxpayers' money, and, in the long run, it was completely unsustainable. Our policy solves both of these problems. We're providing sustainable funding growth and making universities accountable. It's a responsible policy that addresses inefficient, unsustainable spending and ensures that future generations will get the most out of their university experience.

By linking funding with performance outcomes, we're incentivising universities to focus their attention on improving academic performance, student retention and employability. The Turnbull government is ensuring new students are going into a system that wants to produce successful and employable graduates. The demand driven system provides more students with the opportunity to attend university and puts those students in the best position to meet the needs of an emerging economy. It also lets universities select the students they want, rather than have a Canberra bean counter determine how many students a university can enrol. The Turnbull government supports the demand driven system. Labor says they support it, but they've continually voted down any opportunity to make that system sustainable. The enduring legacy of the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd years was economic vandalism. Motions like this one show that Labor has learnt nothing from its failures in government and, given the opportunity, they'd thrown us straight back in the same mess. Labor will never face up to the fact we have to live within our means. I value the university experience. Education is the bedrock on which the whole economy exists. That's why I'm proud to be part of a government that's increasing funding for universities and equally proud that we're ensuring that the rate of this increase is sustainable for future generations.

Mr DICK (Oxley) (19:00): Australia's education system is world leading. It supports more than one million students, both international and domestic, and our universities directly employ 120,000 people and support another 40,000 jobs. It must be protected. I'm proud to speak on this motion today and stand up for not only university students and future university students in my electorate but for students rights across this country who have been left short-changed by this government. Make no mistake, this government has taken a wrecking ball to our universities and higher education system, with $2.2 billion cuts since they have come to powerâa simply staggering number that means our universities will be under-resourced and our students will miss out on the vital education they need to succeed in the fast-moving 21st century.

When Labor was last in office we lifted the caps on the high number of uni places, which saw, in my community in Oxley, a huge increase in the number of students attending university. We've seen the complete opposite by this government. Their $2.2 billion axe to our universities means that 9Â½ thousand Australians missed out on a university place in 2018 and another 9Â½ thousand will miss out on a place in 2019. This is just unacceptable. We must be supporting and investing in our universities rather than gutting the institutions that will guide the next generation of scientists, doctors and teachers.

Australia's future economy will require a highly skilled workforce. This government's cuts to our universities do nothing to support that. The government is going out of its way and making deals with One Nation to prove that point. Earlier this year we saw the government make a deal with One Nationâa deal to deliver tax cuts for the big end of town in exchange for a mere 1,000 apprenticeships, which is nothing more than a pathetic con job. In particular, it is selling out young Australians. We know that, since this government came to power, Australia has lost over 140,000 apprenticeships, a decline of over 35 per cent. In my community we have seen a loss of around 1,500 apprenticeships, which is equivalent to a 43 per cent decrease.

It's not just students looking to go to university who are in the sights of this government but any person wishing to finish their education will pay the price. I know in my own community there are many current high school students who are aiming to be the first in their family to ever go to uni. Many of these students come from tough, disadvantaged backgrounds and are studying and working hard to see their dream of going to uni become a reality. But now, thanks to the Turnbull government, the door to a higher education is being slammed in their face by these vicious cuts to our universities. This is an especially cruel blow to the many year 12 graduates who have studied so hard to get into uni. There are reports of some universities already turning away students and cutting programs before next year begins.

Here's what it means for universities in Queensland in my home state: the University of Southern Queensland, with a campus in my electorate, is facing $36 million in cuts; Griffith University, a cut of $92 million; QUT, a cut of $100 million and the University of Queensland $100 million in cuts. Ironclad evidence that this government does not care about students in the country going to university and receiving a higher education. We know this because they have a track record of tearing down our universities. In fact, they have repeatedly attacked higher education year after year. When they were first elected it was a 20 per cent cut and full fee deregulation, which we know would have seen $100,000 degrees. Fortunately, my Labor colleagues and I were able to stop that, but they weren't done. In the next iteration, last year, they wanted to hike up fees by 7.5 per cent, have a commensurate cut in university funding, have a further cut to university funding and then cut the HECS payment threshold down to as low as $42,000âthat's barely more than the minimum wage and would mean Australians with a HELP debt on low incomes would be required to make repayments. I have to wonder if those opposite are actually aware of where Australia sits in the public investment in universities in the OECD. Are we near the top? Not even close. About midrange? No. Australia has the second-lowest level of public investment in universities in the OECD, and this government only wants to make it worse.

But there is an alternative. A Shorten Labor government, which invests in a higher education system and which believes in students, will have a once-in-a-generation national inquiry which will look at every aspect of our vocational and higher education systems. This will be the first time a national inquiry has put TAFE and unis on an equal footing. It's about ensuring that Australians have access to the best post-secondary opportunities in the world. If Australia is to continue to be a wealthy, highly educated nation, we must participate in quality education. I call on the government tonight to abandon their cuts to universities and instead to invest in Australia's future.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Buchholz ): I call, with some trepidation, the member for Solomon!

Mr GOSLING (Solomon) (19:05): I want to acknowledge the hard work of the member for Griffith, Terri Butler, who joined me in Darwin just a little while ago and who has been a champion in the fight against the government's cuts to regional universities, including ours in Darwin, the Charles Darwin University. The member for Oxley, the previous member, rattled off about four or five universities. We understand that there are many universities in the larger capital cities of our nation, but for our northern capital there is oneâCharles Darwin University. I guess that for this side, universities are not just research centres and places of teaching but part of the foundation on which we want to build a better nation. That's certainly true for us in the Territory. Charles Darwin University, our university, is so important for building the foundations on which we're going to build a better Territory. Education is one of the keys to preparing our society, especially our kids, to understand, anticipate and shape change, not just react to it. We want to build a northern future that really grasps the potential of the north and the massive markets further north.

Unfortunately, the current federal government, under Prime Minister Turnbull, has cut $30 million from our university, which represents a decline of 8.1 per cent in funding. Unfortunately, regional universities are disproportionally affected by the government's decision to cut higher education. We might ask where their priorities might be: if regional universities are missing out, who might not be missing out? Of course, the $17 billion handout to the big banks becomes unconscionable. If they're serious about developing the north and developing the human capacity of Australians then why would they cut funding to universities, particularly to ours?

CDU is ranked in the top two per cent of universities in the world. CDU makes a range of social and economic contributions to the Northern Territory. These things are sometimes hard to quantify, but there are things like improved opportunity for social mobility and cohesion across the north. As all members should know, these cuts place our university's future in jeopardy, which makes no sense. Darwin is on Asia's doorstep and Asia is increasingly hungry for the quality educational opportunities we provide. It should be our No. 1 export. CDU offers a unique chance to study in one of the world's most diverse and spectacular natural and cultural environments, and for many in the tropics to our north, where there are billions of people living, it has a tropical environment where they would feel very much at home when studying with us. Today over 1,500 international students from 50 countries call CDU campuses home. This, obviously, presents huge opportunities for CDU and other regional universities to service the growing education demandâas I said, from Asia in particular. We should be investing heavily in the human and capital infrastructure across our education system to realise this massive opportunity.

Without a viable, active university, our young people often seek to go elsewhere for their education. They'll increasingly do this if CDU isn't properly funded. As a smaller university, like other regional universities, CDU doesn't have the financial depth, flexibility and contacts with the same level of philanthropy as do some of the big sandstones we see in the southern capitals. So we are, without a doubt, disadvantaged in this regard. We've also got a small population size. Many people want to study part time and move in and out of education. This model that CDU uses is a high-cost delivery model, so it makes it challenging financially. So, in case you haven't picked it up yet, we can do without $30 million in cuts to our CDU.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Hogan ): The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

span.span: Federation Chamber adjourned at 19:11

p.span: Â
QUESTIONS IN WRITING
Medicine
(Question No. 864)
Mr Zappia asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 05 December 2017:
(1) How many overseas (a) doctors, and (b) nurses, were granted a work visa in 2016-17.
(2) How many overseas doctors granted a work visa in 2016-17 left Australia before their visa had expired
(3) How many overseas doctors granted a temporary work visa since 1 January 2013 have been granted permanent residency.
Mr Tudge: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
Definitions:

For the purpose of this answer, doctors have been defined as any occupation in ANZSCO code '253 Medical Practitioners'. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) this group is defined as;

MEDICAL PRACTITIONERS diagnose physical and mental illnesses, disorders and injuries, provide medical care to patients, and prescribe and perform medical and surgical treatments to promote and restore good health

For the purpose of this answer, nurses have been defined as any occupation in ANZSCO code '254 Midwifery and Nursing Professionals' or '4114 Enrolled and Mothercraft Nurses'. According to the ABS these groups are defined as;

MIDWIFERY AND NURSING PROFESSIONALS provide care to mothers and their babies, the elderly, and physically and mentally ill patients in hospitals, nursing homes, medical centres and the community; provide clinical education to midwives and nurses; conduct research into clinical nursing practice; and manage health service units and sub-units

ENROLLED AND MOTHERCRAFT NURSES provide nursing care to patients in hospitals, aged care and other health care facilities and in the community, and assist parents in providing care to newborn infants under the supervision of a Registered Nurse or Midwife
(1) (a) Skilled work primary visas granted in 2016-17 by select nominated occupations (doctors):
ANZSCO Nominated Occupation
Temporary
Permanent
253111 General Practitioner
253112 Resident Medical Officer
253211 Anaesthetist
253311 Specialist Physician (General Medicine)
253312 Cardiologist
253313 Clinical Haematologist
253314 Medical Oncologist
253315 Endocrinologist
253316 Gastroenterologist
253317 Intensive Care Specialist
253318 Neurologist
253321 Paediatrician
253322 Renal Medicine Specialist
253323 Rheumatologist

Citizenship
(Question No. 942)
Mr Hill asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 26 February 2018:

(1) Can he provide the geographic breakdown for citizenship ceremonies for citizens (by conferral); if so, can this data be provided by state/territory or local government area (or some other geographic unit), including the number of citizens, for each month from 1 June 2013 until the most recent period for which data is available; if not, can this data be provided by sub-region, region or state/territory, and by month, or quarter, or a similar period from 1 June 2013 until the most recent period.

(2) Does his department review or cross check if new citizens attend a citizenship ceremony; if so, (a) what past period do these reviews cover, (b) what is the purpose of these reviews, and (c) do the reviews target any particular cohorts; if, so which ones.

p.span: Before a citizenship ceremony, the Department of Home Affairs (the Department) sends a pledge verification list to the ceremony organisers which lists all the applicants that have been invited to attend. Prior to the ceremony attendees are registered by ceremony organisers. Following the ceremony, the presiding officer must sign the pledge verification list, confirming that each person on the list has attended the ceremony and made the pledge of commitment. The names of people who failed to attend the ceremony or make the pledge are deleted by the presiding officer ruling through their names on the list. The list is then returned to the Department so that people who attended and made the pledge can be registered as citizens.

Regular departmental reports are run to determine those applicants that have been approved but have not yet acquired citizenship through making the pledge at a citizenship ceremony. State and territory offices actively manage these cases, including contacting clients to provide them with the opportunity to provide reasons for their non-attendance. No particular cohort is targeted for this ongoing activity.
Remediation Works
(Question No. 961)
Ms Butler asked the Minister for Defence Personnel, in writing, on 08 May 2018:

(1) Would he (a) particularise the remediation works that have been carried out by the Government at the Bulimba Barracks site, and (b) list any remediation work that would need to be undertaken before the Bulimba Barracks site could be re-developed, but which has not been undertaken by the Government.(2) Is the Bulimba Barracks site presently contaminated by (a) leaking from underground tanks, (b) hydrocarbon impact from the previous fuel storage point, (c) solvents, degreasers or other caustic or alkaline solutions, or (d) asbestos-containing material.(3) Are there presently elevated radiation levels in surface soil at the Bulimba Barracks site.
Mr Chester: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
a) Following completion of a Stage 1 Environmental Investigation, in 2015 Defence undertook remediation works to remove tritium from the Bulimba Barracks site.

In December 2015, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) advised Defence that the remediation activities were completed successfully and ARPANSA removed Bulimba Barracks from its register. Defence has completed the recommended remediation work to address contaminants unique to Defence activities.

b) Defence's environmental advisor is in the process of finalising the Bulimba Barracks Stage 2 Detailed Site Environmental Investigation report. The initial findings of the Stage 2 Detailed Site Environmental Investigation suggest that contaminants present on site represent a low to medium risk for future use, and that the contamination sources are not unusual for a typical metropolitan redevelopment site. Defence has been advised that industry is well equipped to undertake and complete any necessary remediation to prepare the site for future development. Defence will make its investigation report available to eligible purchasers to inform planning for future site development.

a) There are two septic tanks underground. There are three small above ground fuel tanks and one small underground fuel tank on the site. The detailed site investigation is examining these potential sources, and has found that the contamination from the septic tanks is very limited and localised to the source location. Soil testing has shown that there is no evidence of the fuel tanks leaking.
b) The detailed site investigation is examining the potential for contaminants from the fuel storage point and has found that there is no evidence of contamination.

c) The detailed site investigation is examining the potential for residues from solvents, degreasers and other cleaning products in the specific location where these were used for vehicle maintenance. No contamination has been detected.
d) A number of buildings on the site were constructed using asbestos containing material. The asbestos is intact and contained within the building fabric.

3. The 2015 radiation assessment, undertaken by Queensland Health Scientific Services, cleared the former electronics workshop, Building C006, which was used for the manufacture and maintenance of instrumentation that contains Gaseous Tritium Light Devices (GTLD). Tritium is a source of beta radiation. The comprehensive assessment of radiation in 2015 cleared the building and surrounds of radiological impact. This clearance was confirmed by the ARPANSA.

p.span: Question 2:

Under the Australian Citizenship Act 2007 (Cth) (the Citizenship Act), a person who is stateless can apply for Australian citizenship if certain legislative criteria are met. Under subsection 21(8) of the Citizenship Act, a person is eligible to become an Australian citizen if the Minister for Home Affairs (or his/her delegate) is satisfied that the person was born in Australia, and is not a national or citizen of any country, and has never been and is not entitled to acquire the nationality or citizenship of another country, and meets certain other legislative criteria that also applied to non-stateless persons.
National Disability Insurance Scheme
(Question No. 970)
Ms McGowan asked the Minister for Social Services, in writing, on 10 May 2018:
(1) In respect of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), what are the nominated timeframes between a plan
(a) being submitted to the NDIS and it being approved,
(b) being approved by NDIS and its implementation for the client, and

(c) being lodged for a review by the client and the outcome.(2) How does the planning process allow for clients to have a final check of their draft plan for accuracy and agreement before it is sent to the NDIS for approval?(3) Why do clients who receive final plans that are inadequate have to wait for up to a year, or more, to have their plans reviewed?(4) What steps is the department taking to address the high number of plans waiting for review.

(5) What mechanisms are in place for clients to question decisions in their final plan without fear of being penalised?(6) What flexibility is there in current policy for National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) plan approvers to determine what is 'reasonable and necessary' to meet a client's individual needs.(7) What governance is there to ensure the policy wording, 'reasonable and necessary', is applied on a case by case basis to ensure individual needs are met.(8) Why are there discrepancies in the approval of services which see one client being approved for only 10 hours of therapy and another client approved for 20 hours when they have similar needs?(9) Under what circumstances are respite and transport not deemed to be 'reasonable and necessary' for a client to request.(10) Under what circumstance would the provision of paying internet cost for a bed-bound quadriplegic not be deemed to be 'reasonable and necessary'.(11) In respect of Support Coordinators,
(a) why is there a delay in coordinators being assigned to clients once this service has been approved in their individual plan,
(b) what is the average wait time,
(c) are there related performance indicators, and

(d) are these being met.(12) How do the targets given for NDIS workers to transition people onto the NDIS allow enough time for the worker to spend with each client to make sure they fully understand the client's needs.(13) How do current targets governing the number of people NDIS workers have to sign up and transition to the NDIS allow enough time to be spent with clients/families, for an appropriate assessment to be done to ensure individual needs are met.(14) Will the current pilot-program 'Side-by-Side' be rolled out into regional areas?(15) What are the plans for increasing staffing levels of NDIS workers in regional centres?(16) What educational qualification or prior experience in working with people with disabilities, is required for NDIS planners and approvers?
Mr Tehan: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) does not currently have nominated timeframes between plan submission for approval and plan approval, and between plan approval and implementation.

On 15 May 2018, the Commonwealth Ombudsman publically released a report into the NDIA's administration of reviews. The report included recommendations to establish KPIs or agreed service standards for completion of unscheduled plan reviews and internal reviews. The NDIA accepts all of the Ombudsman's recommendations and has commenced the implementation of the report's recommendations.

(2) A new planning approach is being piloted in Victoria as part of the new participant pathway. This includes a joint planning meeting (aka 'side-by-side' planning) between the participant, their Local Area Coordinator and an NDIA planner. During this meeting, the participant is fully engaged in the development of their plan and can ask questions and make minor amendments before their plan is finalised. The NDIA will progressively roll out key features of the new pathway which have been piloted from mid-2018.

(3) The NDIA has received a higher than expected number of requests for participant initiated plan reviews under the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (NDIS Act) â both Section 100 Reviews (Review of a Reviewable Decision) and Section 48 Reviews (Plan Review due to a Change of Circumstances). The high volume of review requests has resulted in an increased wait time for NDIS participants.
(4) Work has commenced on a number of strategies and initiatives to improve the administration of reviews in the NDIA. These strategies include:
a) reviewing and re-designing end-to-end processes and supporting guidance for requesting and completing reviews;

b) reviewing practice guides and developing scripts and talking points for front-of-house, business support officers, the Centralised Regional Response Team (CRRT) and National Contact Centre (NCC) staff to help participants understand the review process and pathway;
c) developing and implementing processes for contacting participants who have a pending request and informing them of the process moving forward;
d) formalising a triage approach to prioritise urgent cases;

e) identifying the drivers contributing to the higher than expected level of requests that can then be addressed. A Business Improvement Team has been established to implement system and practice changes to this effect;

f) establishing the Assistive Technology and Home Modification Redesign Project, as well as interim improvements to existing processes â it is recognised that requests relating to assistive technology and home modification drive a notable portion of review requests; and
g) building on planned improvements to the NDIS business system.

(5) All internal reviews of a decision are conducted by a staff member who was not involved in the original decision. If the participant is dissatisfied with the internal review of the decision, they can apply for an external review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT).

(6) NDIA plan delegates consider a participant's individual support needs, informal, community and mainstream supports available as part of a planning conversation and apply the NDIS Act and Rules when determining what 'reasonable and necessary' supports will be included in the participant's NDIS plan.
NDIS Operational Guidelines provide additional information regarding planning and specific supports to assist the plan approver in their decision making.

(7) 'Reasonable and necessary' supports are governed by the NDIS Act (section 34 1. (a) â (f), 34. 2) and the NDIS (Supports for Participants) Rules. The NDIA delegate (approver) must be satisfied that all of the section 34 1. (a) â (f) criteria are met before supports are funded or provided by the NDIS.

(8) Each NDIS participant will have their own plan goals, personal circumstances and disability support needs. While some participants may appear to have similar support needs, their individual situation may indicate different support responses to meet their needs.

(9) Transport may not be considered a reasonable and necessary support if a participant can use public transport without substantial difficulty due to their disability. Some participants may receive funded supports to improve their community access and transport performances such as training supports to develop their skills to use public transport, or vehicle modifications to travel or drive a private vehicle. The day-to-day cost that any Australian would incur for their personal travel needs such as public transport fares or vehicle ownership, would not be considered a reasonable and necessary support

Respite may not be considered a reasonable and necessary support if this support did not account for what is reasonable to expect families to provide, particularly with regard to the provision of care and support for participants who are children; or when a participant can be supported to improve their ability to do things for themselves.

(10) The cost associated with an internet service is considered a day-to-day living cost that anyone with this type of service would be required to pay. For some day-to-day living costs, there may be additional costs due to a participant's disability. For this to be considered a reasonable and necessary support, the NDIS would require evidence that this additional cost is solely and directly as a result of their disability support needs.

(11) Participants select the provider of Support Coordination from those that are available in their location. Support coordination providers are expected to only accept the request if they have capacity to support participants within two working days of receiving the request for service. Support providers are encouraged to decline the request and advise the participant and the NDIA region if they do not have capacity at this moment in time.

(12) The participant pathway outlines the information gathering process to ensure that the worker understands the participant's needs. The time spent with the participant can vary according to the needs of the participant.

(13) The current targets governing the number of people NDIS workers transition to the NDIS is considered in the resourcing allocation while recognising that the time spent with a participant can vary.

(15) As the NDIS continues to transition across Australia, there will be a requirement to increase staffing levels in some regional centres. The increase in staffing, and the recruitment associated with it, will be in line with participant phasing as set out in the bilateral agreements.

(16) Position descriptions contain a generic skillset the NDIA seeks when recruiting, however, there is no specific qualification or prior experience the NDIA requires when recruiting planners. Most of the planners have worked in the disability sector in jurisdictions.
Mobile Black Spot Program
(Question No. 971)
Ms Cathy McGowan asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, in writing, on 10 May 2018.
(1) In respect of the Mobile Black Spots Program (MBSP), what are (a) the purpose and objectives, and (b) the parameters around provision of funding.
(2) What are the key performance indicators, how are they measured, have they been met, and if not
what action has been taken to meet them in the future.
(3) Is population coverage part of the MBSP location selection criteria and is achieving the greatest population coverage prioritised over other considerations.
(4) Does geographical location influence the funding quantum.
(5) Is a cost benefit analysis, including consideration of population coverage, completed on each tower.
(6) On what basis was the allocation of funding between towers determined.
(7) How many towers have launched to the end of April2018 under each round of the MBSP.
(8) What was the process for selecting the successful bid for a tower build where there was more than one bidder.
(9) Are tower locations developed in consultation with the community and have any changed
location, subsequent to approval for funding, as a result of community input.
(10) How many complaints have been received about the location of a tower under the MBSP.

(11) In respect of complaints relating to the potential for greater coverage by choosing a nearby location, (a) how many have been received, (b) what is the process to investigate complaints about locations, and (c) what has the Government done to manage these complaints.
Mr Fletcher â The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) (a) The MBSP's purpose and objectives are "to extend mobile phone coverage and competition" (see paragraph 1.1.2 of the round 1 Program Guidelines, paragraph 1.1.1 of the Round 2 Program Guidelines and paragraph 1.1.1 of the Priority Locations Round Guidelines).
(1) (b) The processes for awarding funding under the program, including the selection process and assessment criteria, are set out in the Program Guidelines for each round of the program.
As outlined in the Program Guidelines, all three rounds of the program used competitive assessment processes to award funding.

Under these processes, mobile network operators (the operators) and mobile network infrastructure providers (providers) were asked to come forward with proposals to build new or upgraded mobile base stations to deliver improved mobile coverage to identified black spots.

Under rounds 1 and 2, the operators were required to propose base station locations that would deliver improved mobile coverage to one or more of the locations on the database of black spots reported by members of the public. These proposals were assessed and ranked on a base-station-byÂ­ base-station basis according to the assessment criteria outlined in the Program Guidelines. These criteria included the expected benefits that each base station would deliver, such as the amount of new coverage (by square kilometre), the number of premises and the length of major transport routes to receive new mobile coverage.

Consideration was also given to the total cost of the base station. This included the amount of funding the provider was contributing and any co-contribution the provider had secured from a third party such as state or local government. Commonwealth funding per base station was nominally capped at $500,000. The Department of Communications and the Arts was able to recommend a base station for funding which exceeded the cap, so long as it offered value for money to the Commonwealth.

Under the Priority Locations round, the operators were asked to submit proposals to provide improved coverage at pre-announced priority locations. Proposed base stations were then individually assessed and ranked. The assessment process used a cost/coverage formula as specified in the Program Guidelines. Other factors, including coverage to premises and transport routes, were also considered as part of a value for money assessment for each proposed base station.
Each location recommended for funding was assessed as providing value for money to the Commonwealth.

(2) The funding recipients are required to meet specific performance metrics for each base station as set out in their respective funding agreements, including expected performance metrics for new handheld coverage, new external antenna coverage, number of premises to receive coverage and coverage to major transport routes.

The funding recipients are required to report on these metrics for each base station once the base station is activated. The Commonwealth is not required to pay for base stations that do not meet their performance requirements unless changes to the performance metrics were approved by the Commonwealth prior to the construction of a base station. The Commonwealth will only agree to changes to performance metrics in exceptional circumstances where all other options have been exhausted, and only if the changes to performance metrics still represent overall value for money.

To date, one completed base station did not meet the agreed performance requirements. In this case it was not technically possible for the funding recipient to resolve the shortfall in performance through any modification to site specifications (e.g. change in location, increase in tower height, etc). While the base station still provided benefit to the community, a reduced Commonwealth payment for this base station was made reflecting the performance difference and to ensure it still represented value for money.

(3) As a measure of population density, under rounds 1 and 2 the Department of Communications and the Arts considered premises covered during the assessment process. Other benefits offered by a proposed base station were also considered in the assessment, such as the provision of handheld coverage, external antenna coverage and coverage to major transport routes. These benefits were considered for each proposed base station in order to assess the overall benefit to the community and to inform the overall value for money of the base station to the Commonwealth.

Under the Priority Locations round, proposed base stations were assessed using a cost over coverage formula. A value for money assessment was also applied which considered the amount of premises to receive mobile coverage from the proposed base station.

Importantly, the mobile network operators have a commercial incentive to increase population coverage to the maximum extent possible. This drives providers to obtain the best coverage outcomes possible from every location.

(4) The geographical location and local topography influences both the cost and the commercial viability of a base station. For example, hilly topography can severely limit the amount of coverage achieved by a base station and can also result in higher deployment costs. Additionally, more remote base stations are typically more expensive to deploy and are often in lower populated areas, affecting their commercial viability.

The cost of a base station can also be dramatically affected by a small movement in location. For example, moving a base station a small distance to a higher location can add considerable cost if new road works are required or power and backhaul infrastructure needs to be further extended.

The Program Guidelines for rounds 1 and 2 included equitable distribution principles that sought to share the benefits of the program nationally to the best extent possible. These principles included recommending at least ten base stations for funding in each of the states and five in the Northern Territory, and recommending at least one base station for funding in each electorate which had less than 50 per cent of the electorate area as a pat1 of a Major Urban Centre. However, base stations were still required to provide tangible benefits to the community and value for money to the Commonwealth.

Further , under the round 2 assessment process, proposed base stations were awarded points if they were in remote or very remote areas of Australia, to encourage proposals in these typically higher cost areas. Round 2 also ensured that at least $10 million of funding was recommended for base stations in remote and very remote areas.
(5) and (6) See answer to questions 1, 2, 3 and 4.
(7) As at 30 April2018, a total of 489 base stations were completed including 363 under round 1
and 126 under round 2.
(8) See answer to questions 1, 2, 3 and 4.
(9) Community views on the location for base stations funded under the program are considered in a number of ways.

Under rounds 1 and 2, the Department of Communications and the Arts wrote to local councils to seek their support and to ask local councils to consider any cash or in-kind co-contributions they may be in a position to make towards the proposed base stations in their area. Under the Priority Locations round, local councils were contacted by either the Minister for Communications or the Minister for Regional Communications seeking the same type of information.

The applicants applying for funding under the competitive assessment process were strongly encouraged to consult with local councils when developing their proposals . The applicants were also provided with contact information for councils.

The state governments also engaged directly with the applicants during the application process, including choosing to contribute to sites which addressed their specific community requirements. As part of this process, the states undertook their own assessments to ensure the base stations they
contributed towards maximised outcomes for their investment.

Additionally, under rounds 1 and 2 of the program Federal Members of Parliament representing electorates which had less than 50 per cent of the electorate area as a part of a Major Urban Centre were invited to draw on their knowledge of specific local issues and nominate up to three locations in their electorate which received additional points under the assessment criteria.

Funding recipients are also required to consult with the community as part of standard planning approval processes. In some instances the exact location of a base station may be revised in response to state or local planning considerations and community concerns, including taking into account any impact on visual amenity . For example, a MBSP funded base station was moved a small distance to better locate it within a paddock to reduce the impact on the farming land.

Correspondence received by the Department of Communications and the Arts to date concerning the location of a base station have related to one or more specific issues, including whether a base station will provide improved coverage to a specific location, requests to have a base station moved
for commercial reasons (rental), concerns about the proximity of a base station to a specific location
or requests to move a base station to achieve different coverage outcomes (including to cover a different black spot).
The Department of Communications and the Arts has received complaints related to the location of a base station for approximately four per cent of funded base stations.

As appropriate, the Department of Communications and the Arts engages with the funding recipient, the complainant and other relevant stakeholders to investigate issues raised. This may include seeking additional information from the complainant and in some cases asking the funding recipient to undertake coverage or cost modelling for specific proposals. The funding recipient may also be asked to directly engage with the complainant on the issue or to discuss a proposal.

A key consideration is to ensure a funded base station delivers the agreed coverage outcomes to the black spot area. In many cases, proposals that seek to move a base station from its original location would result in a substantial reduction in coverage for one part of a community (and the identified black spot) for the benefit of the proposing party. These proposals often result in substantial cost increases and in some cases are also technically infeasible.
Western Sydney Stadium
(Question No. 972)
Ms Owens asked the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, in writing, on 21 May 2018:

(1) Has the Government been approached to provide funding for Western Sydney Stadium (WSS). (2) If the Government has been approached, did it commit to funding WSS; if so, (a) when, and (b) what sum. (3) Has the Government provided funding for WSS; if so, (a) when, and (b) what sum.
Mr Hunt: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes. The Australian Government was approached by the NSW Government to redirect funding previously allocated to the upgrade of Parramatta Stadium to the construction of the WSS.
(2) The Australian Government agreed to the redirection of funding previously allocated to upgrades to Parramatta Stadium, to assist with the construction of the WSS.
(b) $16.4 million redirection of unspent funding previously allocated to the upgrade of Parramatta Stadium.
(3) The Australian Government agreed to the redirection of funding to the WSS.
(a)The original Government commitment for upgrades to Parramatta Stadium was agreed to on 20 June 2013.
(b)The Government is providing $16.4 million to the construction of the WSS, through the redirection of funding previously allocated to the upgrade of Parramatta Stadium.
Climate
(Question No. 973)
Mr Bandt asked the Minister for the Environment and Energy, in writing, on 21 May 2018:

(1) Has (a) he, (b) his ministerial office, or (c) his department, read the report: What Lies Beneath: the Scientific Understatement of Climate Risk (David Spratt and Ian Dunlop, Breakthrough, September 2017).
(2) Has (a) he, (b) his ministerial office, or (c) his department, made any assessment of the propositions made in the report, particularly in respect of existential risk.

(3) Has his department sought advice or assessment from external organisations such as the CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology, or university climate specialists, on the report; if so, what was the nature of this advice, and can he provide it.
(4) Has his department considered the implications for policy-making of climate change being an existential risk to human civilisation.
(5) Can he indicate whether the Cabinet has considered the Government's duty of care and fiduciary responsibility towards Australian citizens in light of the more severe risks raised in the report.
Mr Frydenberg: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Questions 1 and 2

The Department of the Environment and Energy is aware of the publication released in September 2017 by the Breakthrough organisation titled What Lies Beneath: The Scientific Understatement of Climate Risks and is aware of the propositions made in the report.
Questions 3 and 4
The Department of the Environment and Energy regularly seeks science advice from the CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology. This advice informs consideration of policy and program design.
The report does not present new information on climate science and the Department has not commissioned specific advice on its conclusions.
Question 5
It is not appropriate to comment on what matters may or may not have been considered by Cabinet.
Ministerial Responses
(Question No. 974)
Mr Rob Mitchell asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in writing, on 24 May 2018:

When will he respond to my correspondence dated and emailed to his ministerial office on 26 March 2018 (and previously dated and sent by post to his predecessor on 27 November 2017) on matters concerning the Hume Freeway in the electoral division of McEwen.
Mr McCormack: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I responded to the Member for McEwen on 17 May 2018.
Prohibited Weapons
(Question No. 975)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Law Enforcement and Cyber Security, in writing, on 29 May 2018:
What total number of weapons were seized at each Australian airport in the calendar year (a) 2013, (b) 2014, (c) 2015, (d) 2016, (e) 2017, and (f) 2018 (to date).
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

Prohibited Weapons
(Question No. 976)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Law Enforcement and Cyber Security, in writing, on 29 May 2018:

What number of people were (a) fined for, (b) had charges laid for, or (c) were convicted of, carrying a prohibited weapon through security screening at each Australian airport in the calendar year (i) 2013, (ii) 2014, (iii) 2015, (iv) 2016, (v) 2017, and (vi) 2018 (to date).

Airport Security
(Question No. 977)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Law Enforcement and Cyber Security, in writing, on 29 May 2018:

(1) What number of security training exercises involving a deliberate attempt by an official to smuggle a weapon, training bomb or contraband through security were undertaken (a) with notice, and (b) without notice, at each Australian airport in the calendar year (i) 2013, (ii) 2014, (iii) 2015, (iv) 2016, (v) 2017, and (vi) 2018 (to date). (2) By item and airport, what number of the above mentioned items made it through security without detection.
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
The Department shares the results of its exercises with individual airports to assist in continual improvement. For security reasons this information is not released publicly.
Airport Security
(Question No. 978)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Law Enforcement and Cyber Security, in writing, on 29 May 2018:

(1) What proportion (as a percentage) of bags or cargo loaded onto outbound aircraft at each Australian (a) international, and (b) domestic, airport is x-rayed. (2) If less than 100 per cent of the above is screened, why.
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

The majority of baggage on screened air services is screened by x-ray examination. X-ray is also a primary method of air cargo screening. For items that cannot be x-rayed, due to their size or other physical characteristics, there are alternative screening methods in place.
For obvious security reasons, the Department does not discuss the details of how security screening is conducted.
Airport Security
(Question No. 979)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Law Enforcement and Cyber Security, in writing, on 29 May 2018:

Since 1 January 2013, has the Government received advice from any security agencies relating to failures or security gaps with the screening of (a) passengers, (b) baggage, or (c) cargo, at Australian airports; if so, (i) what was the advice, and (ii) has the advice been implemented.
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

The Department of Home Affairs receives regular and ad hoc briefings from various security agencies. Those briefings are reflected in the risk assessments that underpin our compliance activities, including those undertaken at Australian airports by our Aviation and Maritime Security Division.
For obvious security reasons, the Department does not discuss the details of advice received from security agencies.
Airport Security
(Question No. 980)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Law Enforcement and Cyber Security, in writing, on 29 May 2018:

Since 1 January 2013, has the Government received advice from security agencies about (a) an increased risk to public safety from the use of labour hire staff versus traditional, security cleared, full time airport staff, and (b) the risks associated with poor training and/or excessive working hours related to airport security staff.
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
No.
For obvious security reasons, the Department does not discuss the details of advice received from security agencies.
Airport Security
(Question No. 981)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Law Enforcement and Cyber Security, in writing, on 29 May 2018:

(1) Since 1 January 2013, what proportion (as a percentage) of labour-hire security staff at each Australian airport have not received security checks by ASIO and the AFP but are working in security areas on temporary passes.
(2) What is the average length of time (a) for a security clearance to be processed, and (b) that a security contractor operates in the field without a completed security check.
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

A security guard at an airport from which a regular public transport operation operates must hold and display a valid aviation security identification card (ASIC) (regulation 5.04 of the Aviation Transport Security Regulations 2005 (the Regulations)).

Similarly, a security screening officer must also hold and display a valid ASIC (regulation 5.07 of the Regulations). The only exception to this is for a person training to be a security screening officer who has applied for an ASIC, is not making independent screening decisions, and is constantly supervised by a qualified screening officer (who must hold and display a valid ASIC).

All ASIC holders have undergone a background check, including a criminal history check undertaken by the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission (ACIC) and a security check undertaken by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO).
Approximately 50 percent of ASIC background checks are completed within five business days, and 90 percent are completed within 15 business days.
Airport Security
(Question No. 982)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Law Enforcement and Cyber Security, in writing, on 29 May 2018:

(1) Can he provide the number of domestic passengers in Australia who have or are estimated to have successfully travelled on the ticket of another passenger in the calendar year (a) 2013, (b) 2014, (c) 2015, (d) 2016, (e) 2017, and (f) 2018 (to date).
(2) What is he doing to ensure that domestic travellers on the 'no fly list' do not fly on the ticket of another passenger?
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
(1) The Government does not hold this information.

(2) As part of the 2018-19 Budget, the Australian Government announced measures to further strengthen Australia's domestic and international aviation security. The measures included more than 190 additional AFP officers, and new laws to give police broader powers to conduct identity checks at airports and to order a person to 'move on' from airport premises where they pose a threat to aviation security.
National Disability Insurance Scheme
(Question No. 983)
Mrs Elliot asked the Minister for Social Services, in writing, on 18 June 2018:
Is funding guaranteed under the NDIS for people assessed as Level 1 and Level 2 autism spectrum disorder?
Mr Tehan: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) assesses each application for National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) eligibility on a case-by-case basis and there are no conditions or disabilities considered to have 'guaranteed funding'.

NDIA assessors use the published operational guidelines 'List A' (which can be accessed at www.ndis.gov.au/operational-guideline/access/list-a) and 'List B' (which can be accessed at www.ndis.gov.au/operational-guideline/access/list-b)when considering a prospective participant's eligibility for the NDIS.The absence of a condition from List A or List B is not indicative of ineligibility.
Any person with autism who is eligible for the NDIS will continue to receive the reasonable and necessary supports they are assessed as needing.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (Question No. 1003)

p.span: Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority
(Question No. 1003)
Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources, in writing, on 26 June 2018:

1. Have any reviews been conducted by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) since the approval in 2015 of the use of SumiLarv Granular (pyriproxyfen) in potable water containers and rain water tanks.
2. Specifically, has the APVMA considered recent evidence that pyriproxyfen activates Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor (PPAR) gamma.
3. 3What modelling has been done by the APVMA to examine the likely effects of pyriproxyfen treated water on PPAR gamma.

4. What has the APVMA determined to be a safe level of PPAR gamma activation/PPAR gamma agonist exposure, in terms of heart health and the risk of congestive heart failure, and how was this level determined.
5. What other countries have approved the use of pyriproxyfen in drinking water/potable water containers.
Mr Littleproud: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

1. No â formal reconsideration under Division 4 of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Act 1994 has not occurred, as risks have not been identified that require such reconsideration. The APVMA routinely evaluates all new, relevant data, reviews, and evaluations by peer-reviewed published researchers, comparable overseas and international regulatory bodies, relating to all active constituents including pyriproxyfen. The APVMA will re-evaluate the Australian health based guidance values and approved uses at a later date if evidence indicates that such action is needed.

Pyriproxyfen has been repeatedly evaluated by the World Health Organisation (WHO). The WHO Pesticide Evaluation Scheme re-confirmed pyriproxyfen's pre-qualification status (including use drinking water sources) for control of disease carrying mosquitos and other disease vectors on 28 July 2017.
2. Yes. All of the recent evidence supports the current Australian health based guidance values for pyriproxyfen.
3. The APVMA has not undertaken modelling and â based on an evaluation of the most recent published data on this topic â concluded that no further modelling is required at this time.

4. There is no evidence of such effects due to pyriproxyfen exposure in mammals or humans exposed up to at the existing health based guidance values. The current evidence supports the established Australian health based guidance values.

5. Pyriproxyfen is approved for use in potable water in a number of countries including Australia, Singapore and Brazil. The WHO Pesticide Evaluation Scheme re-confirmed pyriproxyfen's pre-qualification status (including use drinking water sources) for control of disease carrying mosquitos and other disease vectors on 28 July 2017. Furthermore, the WHO/London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine Malaria Consortium has recommended the use of pyriproxyfen in drinking water for the control of dengue virus transmission by mosquitos.
